. I promised to put some light on this bug.
tuple_alloc shifts a tuple pointer and uses this extra space to store field_map:
char *ptr = (char *) salloc(total, "tuple");
    struct tuple *tuple = (struct tuple *)(ptr + format->field_map_size);
salloc_index_to_ptr always returns the original pointer. 
There is no way to get shifted pointer from original because the size of field_map cannot be determined.
. test/box/bitset.lua works with (num, num) tuples. Such kind of tuples do not need the offset table, because offsets can be precalculated and saved in the tuple format definition.
BITSET need a (tuple <-> some_number_id) mapping where the right space is very dense.
ptr_to_index is not so good approximation to the ideal mapping, but it was best that I could implement in our architecture. Replacing ptr_to_index with tuple pointer make BITSET very sparse and therefore ineffective.
Possible ways to fix the bug:
1. Remove the ugly hack which shifting pointers and move all offsets to the end of tuple
2. Try to find a better way to enumerate tuples in the space

. bad_trigger.test.py tests exception in session.on_connect() trigger. If such exception happens Tarantool sends an error message after IPROTO_GREETING:
telnet 127.0.0.1 3301
Trying 127.0.0.1...
Connected to 127.0.0.1.
Escape character is '^]'.
Tarantool 1.6.2-137-g6bc40f4                                   
dIZpQWFs1VMlztISUWQ4e38OrgWr+Bpdavvna6wU7R8=                   
[some msgpack]master/test/var/./box.lua:12: attempt to call global 'nosuchfunction' (a nil value)Connection closed by foreign host.
This is undocumented behaviour of Tarantool.
Client usually don't except anything else IPROTO_GREETING on connect. 
Moreover, it is very tricky to implement such error check using blocking sockets (e.g. Python driver) because you don't know how many bytes should be read after greeting. I think most connect author will not implement it.
We need a design decision here.

. I don't want to start a holy war, but IMHO dot notation in box.space was totally misused.
From Lua 5.2 manual *

To represent records, Lua uses the field name as an index. The language supports this representation by providing a.name as syntactic sugar for a["name"].

In other words, Lua Team designed dot syntax to access properties of complex structures/records.
Let's take a look on two example:
person = { fullname = "Alexander", age = 35  };
print(person.fullname)
person is a complex data structure
fullname is a property of person record
persons_by_name = {}
persons_by_name['Alexander'] = person
persons_by_name.Alexander -- uncommon usage
persons_by_name is a map of elements
Alexander is a member of persons_by_name map.
I think that box.space['users'].index['primary'] is more readable than
box.space.users.index.primary.  Please also note that you can't use reserved
keywords in dot notation!
I suggest:
1. Do not forbid dots in space names
2. Use array subscription syntax to access box.space and box.space['name'].index members in our test and manuals.
3. Save box.space['name'] to a local variable when a space is accessed multiple times (for performance reasons).
Let's discuss this topic.
. I checked Lua grammar.  Their grammar for identifiers is
< NAME: ["a"-"z", "A"-"Z", "_"] (["a"-"z", "A"-"Z", "_", "0"-"9"])* >
I will add similar checks for space, index and user names.
. IPROTO CALL currently supports object notation (: syntax) and we may add support for [] syntax as well. I think that _func table should support same conventions as IPROTO CALL. In other words, function name in _func table is not an identifier, it is an expression.

nosqlbench - to benchmark performance via network protocol

. Final decision is made by @kostja.
CALL should return arbitrary MsgPack objects. Multireturn values (select('#', ...) > 1) should be encoded into MsgPack array.
Example tests cases:
- return 1 => 1
- return 1, 2, 3 => [1, 2, 3]
- return true | false | nil => true | false | nil
- return nil => nil
- return {} => [] - MsgPack array
- return {1} => 1
- return {1, 2, 3} => [1, 2, 3]
- return {1, 2, 3}, {'a', 'b', 'c'}, {true, false} => [[1, 2, 3], ['a', 'b', 'c'], [true, false]]
- return {key1 = 'value1', key2 = 'value2'} => {'key1': 'value1', 'key2': 'value2'} - MsgPack map
- return tuple => tuple
- return tuple, tuple, tuple => [ tuple, tuple, tuple]
- return {tuple, tuple, tuple} => [ tuple, tuple, tuple ]
map vs array should be detected in the same way as it done in the current implementation of Lua MsgPack binding.

. # Proposed Changes
box.fiber
Changes:
box.fiber.id(obj) => box.fiber.id() (for current fiber) + obj:id()
box.fiber.name(obj) => box.fiber.name() (for current fiber) + obj:name()
box.fiber.status(obj) => box.fiber.status() (for current fiber) + obj:status()
box.fiber.resume(obj) => obj:resume()
box.fiber.find() => box.fiber[id]
box.fiber.cancel(obj) => box.fiber.cancel(id) + obj:cancel() (or box.fiber.kill(id) ?)
Not changed:
box.fiber.create()
box.fiber.yield()
box.fiber.sleep()
box.fiber.info()
box.fiber.wrap()
box.fiber.create()
box.fiber.testcancel()
box.fiber.self()
box.session
New functions:
box.session[id] - finds session by id
box.session.self() - returns current session object
Changes:
box.session.id() => obj:id()
box.session.fd() => obj:fd()
box.session.uid() => obj:uid() (or may be box.session.user():id() ?)
box.session.user() => returns current user
box.session.peer(id) => obj:peer()
box.session.exists(id) => remove
Not changed:
box.session.su()
box.session.on_connect()
box.session.on_disconnect()
box.session.storage()

. @pgulutzan: please update documentation.
uuid = require 'uuid' -- load uuid module
uu = uuid.new() -- create new UUID object
uu = uuid() -- create new UUID object (an alias)
uu = uuid.fromstring(str) -- parse UUID from RFC4122 format, returns nil on error
uu = uuid.frombin(bin [, byteorder]) -- decode UUID from binary
uu1 == uu2 -- compares two uuids for equality
uu:str() -- format UUID to RFC4122 string
tostring(uu) -- same as uu:str()
uu:bin(byteorder) -- encode UUID to binary
uu:isnil() -- true if UUID is nil (00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000)
uuid.NULL -- null UUID object
uuid.str() -- alias for uuid():str()
uuid.bin([byteorder]) -- alias for uuid():bin([byteorder])
byteorder is 'l' - little, 'b' - big, 'h' - host (default), 'n' - network 
UUID library always generates RFC4122-compatible UUID version 1 (time + hw address) or version 4 (random), depending on platform. Please note in the documentation that generator makes at least one syscall. In other words, this operation is not so fast.

. @pgulutzan could you please also mention in the documentation  yaml.NULL, json.NULL and msgpack.NULL constants. These constants can be used instead of nil in tables when passing as argument to {yaml|msgpack|json}.encode() . Lua doesn't store nil values in tables and therefore it is not possible encode NULL values properly.
Example:
```
tarantool> print(yaml.encode({1, 2, nil, 4, 5}))

1: 1
2: 2
4: 4
5: 5
...
tarantool> print(yaml.encode({1, 2, yaml.NULL, 4, 5}))


1
2
null
4
5
...

. -  Extra 'p' modifier is not needed anymore:
```
tarantool> box.space.space0:insert({999, 1, 2, 3})


[999, 1, 2, 3]
...
tarantool> box.space.space0:update({999}, {{'+', 2, 1}})



[999, 1, 3, 3]

```
box.pack is not needed:

```
tarantool> box.space.space0:replace({999, 'splice <> test'})


[999, 'splice <> test']
...
tarantool> box.space.space0:update({999}, {{':', 1, 8, 0, 'XXX'}})

...
```

```
tarantool> box.space.space0:replace({999, 'one', 'three'})


[999, 'one', 'three']
...
tarantool> box.space.space0:update({999}, {{'!', 2, 'two'} })



[999, 'one', 'two', 'three']
...
```
. BTW, it is also possible to add tables and other types to tuple:

```
tarantool> box.space.space0:replace({999, 1, 2, 3})


[999, 1, 2, 3]
...
tarantool> box.space.space0:update({999}, {{'!', -1, {1, 2, 3, { 'some', 'objects'} }} })



[999, 1, 2, 3, [1, 2, 3, ['some', 'objects']]]
...
```

Please also note that :update({999}, ...) and :update(999, ...) are interchangeable for non-table keys. space:select() and other methods also supports key == nil (handled as {}).

Change executeReplace()/executeInsert() to check the indexed field of primary key for NULL
   and replace it by nextval() when field is NULL or update the linked sequence otherwise.
   Multipart and non-numeric primary keys with sequences will not be supported.

Don't add auto_increment=true index option from this spec


Don't add a new IPROTO command


Deprecate space:auto_increment() method and remove it somewhere in the future.. We discussed with @unera.

I think that this hang problem is related to bugs in box.net.box.
. console.connect(host, port) uses require('net.box'):new(host, port) which in turn uses require('socket').getaddrinfo(host, port, {protocol = 'tcp'}) under the hood.
You tried to connect to host 0 ==  '0.0.0.0' and port 3301. 0.0.0.0 usually means any ip address. I have no idea what RFC say about connection to "any ip address", but in practice it connects to one of local IP addresses.
Furthermore, a number is fully valid ipv4 address. For example, 134744072 is equivalent to 8.8.8.8.

. YAML has more than one way to encode the same data.
block mode
http://www.yaml.org/spec/1.2/spec.html#Block
```
tarantool> { 1, 2, {key1 = 'val1', key2 = 'val2', array = {'a', 'b', 'c'}}, 3}




1


2
key1: val1
    key2: val2
    array:
a
b
c


3
...
```

flow mode
http://www.yaml.org/spec/1.2/spec.html#Flow
```
tarantool> box.tuple.new({ 1, 2, {key1 = 'val1', key2 = 'val2', array = {'a', 'b', 'c'}}, 3})


[1, 2, {'key1': 'val1', 'key2': 'val2', 'array': ['a', 'b', 'c']}, 3]
...
```

The source string in your example was encoded to block style and the result string was encoded to flow style. However, both YAML strings are fully equivalent and are used to represent the same data structure.
Third-party Lua-YAML library was extended by our team to support flow mode after complaints from customers to output from admin console and REPL in 1.6. Most people want to see Lua tables and Tarantool tuples to be encoded in flow mode. We also added a hint for serializers to choose between array vs map types and block vs flow modes properly: 
```
tarantool> setmetatable({key1 = 'val1', key2 = 'val2'}, { __serialize='map' })


{key1: val1, key2: 'val2'}
...

tarantool> setmetatable({key1 = 'val1', key2 = 'val2'}, { __serialize='mapping' })

key1: val1
  key2: val2
...

tarantool> setmetatable({1, 2, 3}, { __serialize='seq' })

[1, 2, 3]
...

tarantool> setmetatable({1, 2, 3}, { __serialize='sequence' })



1


2
3
...
```

The __serialize feature is nearly fresh and isn't documented yet (WIP).
YAML decoder sets __serialize='seq' and __serialize='map' to sequences and mappings correspondingly to force correct types and flow mode.  I'm not sure that another default value will be acceptable to all. We'll think about it.
Anyway, at least decode() should set proper value based on source input.

. I discussed this problem with @bigbes:
- Official homebrew repository doesn't allow live (e.g. git) formulas, so it is not possible to build Tarantool directly from GitHub using official brew.
- brew validates hard-coded in the formula checksum to match the tarball checksum, so it is not possible to just create dynamic tarantool-1.6.tar.bz on our web-site with the latest version of Tarantool.
- Any modification of formulas is only possible via GitHub pull requests. Review can take up to two weeks.
=> There is no way to automatically upload latest Tarantool to official brew repository for each build using our buildbot. 
Acceptable solution:
1) Create a custom brew repository (brew tap) on http://tarantool.org/dist/ with the latest version of Tarantool. 
https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew/blob/master/share/doc/homebrew/brew-tap.md

@17e I have an experimental code for that:
```
local function tomoney(str)
    local sep = str:find(".", 1, true)
    local kopecks = 0
    if sep then
        kopecks = str:sub(sep + 1)
        local roubles = str:sub(1, sep - 1)
        if #kopecks == 2 then
            kopecks = tonumber(kopecks)
        elseif #kopecks == 1 then
            kopecks = tonumber(kopecks) * 10
        elseif #kopecks == 0 then
            kopecks = 0
        else
           die('Invalid amount: %s', str)
        end
        str = roubles
    end
    if #str == 0 then
        return kopecks
    else
        return tonumber(str) * 100 + kopecks
    end
end
local function frommoney(num)
    num = 0LL + num
    local roubles = tonumber(num / 100)
    local kopecks = math.abs(tonumber(num % 100))
    if roubles == 0 and num < 0 then
        return string.format("-0.%02d", kopecks)
    end
    return string.format("%d.%02d", roubles, kopecks)
end
```

. > "file:/path/to/file" — log to file;

"pipe:/path/to/executable [param1 ...]" — log to a helper process via a pipe;
"syslog:[key=value[,key=value...]]" — log to syslog.
The legacy logger syntax is retained for compatibility. The legacy syntax will be dropped in a future release.

Please keep current syntax - logging to file is most common case.

The syntax is "syslog:" followed by an optional comma separated key=value list. The folowing keys are defined:
identity=... — a string prepended to every syslog message (default: tarantool);
  facility=... — syslog facility (auth, authpriv, cron, daemon, ftp, kern, lpr, mail, news, security, syslog, user, uucp, local0 ... local7, default: user).

. ## Proposed API
```
/
 * Fiber-friendly version of poll(2)
 * Easy to implement using libev, more flexible than bsdsocket_iowait.
 /
int
tnt_poll(struct pollfd *fd, nfds_t nfds, int timeout);
/
 * Shortcut for tnt_poll()
 /
int
tnt_readable(int fd);
/
 * Shortcut for tnt_poll()
 /
int
tnt_writable(int fd);
/
 * Fiber-friendly version of getaddrinfo(3).
 * \sa getaddrinfo().
 * NOTE: already in public API, just rename frm coio_getaddrinfo to tnt_
 * NOTE: Add support for host = "unix/" like in Lua to simplify the code.
 /
int
tnt_getaddrinfo(const char host, const char port,
                const struct addrinfo hints, struct addrinfo res,
                double timeout);
/
 * Connect to remote server.
 * Lua: socket.tcp_connect().
 
 * \return fd of connection
 /
int
tnt_client(struct addrinfo *connect_addr, double timeout);
/
 * \return fd of acceptor
 * Lua: socket.tcp_server().
 /
int
tnt_server(struct addrinfo *listen_addr, double timeout);
```
QA
Q: Where is read/write/connect/close and other functions?
A: Just use berkeley sockets. Berkeley sockets are well-known industrial standard.
I don't see any reason to re-invet the wheel.
Q: Why there is no coio_readahead()/coio_readn()/coio_readw()
A: Because C doesn't have C++ exception. Since you always need to check
result of read(2)/write(2) for -1, you can also check returned size.
Please take a look on bsdsocket code, we don't use bsdsocket:read() and
bsdsocket:write() even in Lua.
Q: Why there is no functions to work with ibuf/obuf.
A: Because I don't want to force developers to use our home-made
buffers. It is always possible to connect any buffer to berkeley sockets
using char *, size or struct iov. Let's discuss about that after adding ibuf/obuf to public API.
Q: Can I create socket without using tnt_client()/tnt_server() functions
A: Yes, just use socket(2) and set O_NONBLOCK flag.
Q: Why tnt_poll()?
A: Because Tarantool have own event-loop under the hood.
tnt_poll() actally uses libev which uses epoll in Linux.
Q: Should I check read(2)/write(2) for EWOULDBLOCK/EAGAIN/EINTR.
A: You should, as usual with berkeley sockets.
Q: Can I wake up fiber in tnt_poll()?
A: You can with fiber_wakeup() (non public right now). tnt_poll() will return ETIMEOUT or EINTR for that case (TBD).
Q: How to wait simulatensly for socket event and fiber_channel event?
A: Probably tnt_poll can be extended to support channels too.
I have no idea how to do that right now, but I think that we can always
add a new function for that (say, tnt_epoll()).

. Discussed on-site. Topic starter wants an explicit method in Lua iterators to free memory, e.g. iterator:close() or iterator:recycle(). I agree that each Lua userdata/cdata should have such method to clean resources before waiting for unpredictable GC. 
. OMG, iterator->close() was removed by b5e873073e4c6c42bad1dcbe815c502eddd80d31.
Could you please cleanup sophia resources just before returning NULL (=end of data) from iterator->next? 
struct tuple *
sophia_iterator_next(struct iterator *ptr)
{
    assert(ptr->next == sophia_iterator_next);
        ....
    obj = fiber_get_key(fiber(), FIBER_KEY_MSG);
    if (obj == NULL)
                /* No more data in iterator, cleanup Sophia resources here */
        return NULL;
This workaround should help in the most common cases

apt-get upgrade, obviously, will restart Tarantool as well as MySQL, PostgreSQL, cron, syslog, dbus and other daemons on your box.  
Debian automatically starts new daemons after install. Debian automatically restarts daemons on upgrade. It is a Debian way. That was a reason @unera extracted init script into a separate  tarantool-common package :
```
apt-cache search "-common$"|wc -l
592
```
It is possible to freeze current version of tarantool-common to prevent upgrades:
apt-mark hold tarantool
Nothing more can be done. Please use apt-get install tarantool to hold tarantool-common package. We follow best practices of distributions rather than re-invent the wheel.
See also #1120

. Detailed explanation:
- Own versioning requires a new source package =>
- A new source package requires a new debian/ folder =>
- A new debian/ folder should be placed at the root directory of git repo for buildbots =>
- Init scripts, tarantoolctl, logrotate, systemd configuration and so on should be extracted from the main git repo into a some new git repo =>
- This change break RPM, homebrew, FreeBSD and other packages =>
- Release engineering process become so much overcomplicated
- I will have to add  some more Conflicts to the main package
- Such big change requires a new review in Debian
RPM doesn't need tarantool-common . I'll remove it in 1.6.8. See explanation of tarantool-common purpose in #1119.

. I checked msgpackffi code again. Unfortunately, it is not possible to implement luaL_serializer logic in msgpackffi, becausepairs()andnext()` functions break JIT trace. The core idea of msgpackffi was to allow JIT in selects. Since msgpackffi cannot be fixed, I close this ticket. Sorry.

. Convert to "raw idea"?
.
    * luaL_tofield tries to classify table into one of four kinds
 * during encoding:
 
 *  + map - at least one table index is not unsigned integer.
 *  + regular array - all array indexes are available.
 *  + sparse array - at least one array index is missing.
 *  + excessively sparse arrat - the number of values missing
 * exceeds the configured ratio.
 
 * An array is excessively sparse when all the following
 * conditions are met:
 
 *  + encode_sparse_ratio > 0.
 *  + max(table) > encode_sparse_safe.
 *  + max(table) > count(table) * encode_sparse_ratio.
 
 * luaL_tofield will never consider an array to be excessively sparse
 * when encode_sparse_ratio = 0. The encode_sparse_safe limit ensures
 * that small Lua arrays are always encoded as sparse arrays.
 * By default, attempting to encode an excessively sparse array will
 * generate an error. If encode_sparse_convert is set to true,
 * excessively sparse arrays will be handled as maps.
```
My code is more flexible and works for most cases. Even Redis uses the same code for detecting Lua arrays.  I can tune up encode_sparse_ratio and encode_sparse_safe. Is it enough?

. > Convenience :)

If fd is nil or -1, it's nice to fall back to just doing a sleep.

socket.iowait(nil, nil, timeout) doesn't look nice for me. There is fiber.sleep(timeout) which actually uses ev_timer under the hood. I don't think that one function can fit all bindings to event machine.

. > make all arguments optional.
My initial point was that one function can't fit all events of the world. iowait() semantics is to wait for some events (read, write or any) on a file descriptor with a specific timeout - socket.iowait(fd, events, timeout). It is clear, understandably and easy to use. I can accept iowait(nil, nil, timeout) because it looks like select(0, NULL, NULL, NULL, timeout) or poll(0, NULL, timeout). Any other combinations likes iowait(fd, nil, timeout) and iowait(nil, 'rw', timeout) are arguable.  uv.new_poll(cq:pollfd()):start(cq:events(), onready) also don't accept nil instead of fd. I don't see any reason to add more ambiguity to iowait() API. Sorry.  Let's try it as is first.

if fd is nil or -1 or events is nil or 0 or the empty string, you don't actually need to watch

-1 is invalid fd which must not be added to the event machine.  Lehman has an assertion for this case in libev and I completely agree with him on that point. 0 is valid file descriptor (usually STDIN), therefore zero must not be used as a special value.

if timeout is nil default to no timer/infinite timeout

It already works in this way.

if timeout is <=0 don't error; just yield the current slice to give other threads a turn e.g. you don't want things to fail if you do logic like: socket.iowait(myfd, "r", deadline - now()) => timeout may end up being negative due to a deadline in the past.

It makes sense. Thank you for pointing this out to me.

5) Tarantool buildbot keep history of all RPM packages for a while.
Fedora:

Packages at final release are kept forever. Of course for updates only the current packages are included, so you could well have an update that isn't the current one that has no debuginfo on mirrors.

Since I plan to upload only minor releases (1.6.x), it would not be a problem. Obviously, I can upload  -debuginfo  to our server after building a new version of package.
Fedora community develops some tools to simplify our life:
- https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Darkserver
- https://github.com/abrt/abrt/wiki/overview
6) fiber.info() is useless for our users. I can make a patch to produce Lua stack traces instead of C stack traces. Lua stack traces will significantly improve debugging of Lua stored procedures.
You can still use gdb and pstack to get C symbol names.
7) I can also try to convince reviewers that we need unstrpped binaries, but I see that we don't.
8) We can continue to build unstripped binaries on our buildbot, but experimentally add packages with debuginfo to Fedora and EPEL7 (= EL7 = CentOS7 ). I don't think that it makes sense since we keep history of -debuginfo forever.
8) RPM packages for Fedora/EPEL7 are intended for new adopters. I think we can go even without fiber.info(). Our enterprise customers will continue to use our "official" repositories.

. > I think this is bug in tonumber64() in tarantool and not in tostring() in lua, because

type(tonumber64("9223372036854775807"))
cdata
type(tonumber64("824708557567779"))
number
and tostring() work correctly only with cdata

This is a desired behavior. The reason is that number is more lightweight then cdata<uint64_t>. 
We've narrowed the range to [-1e14 + 1, 1e14 -1] to make tostring() to be happy. 
You can always convert you numbers to uint64_t using this trick: 0ULL + lua number.

. ### Known limitations and possible caveats
-/etc/init.d/tarantool startunder systemd starts only instances which were enabled before reboot or before lastsystemctl daemon-reload-/etc/init.d/tarantool stopunder systemd does nothing
-systemctl start tarantool(without @instance) starts only instances which were enabled before reboot or before lastsystemctl daemon-reload-systemctl tarantool stop(without @instance) does nothing
- tarantool-1.7.1.142+ package requires newer version oftarantool-commonpackage. An attemp to upgradetarantool-common` will automatically restart all instances.
All these problems are caused by Debian decision to support systemd alongside sysvinit.
Please blame them, not us. 
sysvinit -> systemd conversion guide for Debian/Ubuntu

Install new systemd-enabled packages
For each instancename in /etc/tarantool/instances.enabled/:
systemctl enable tarantool@instancename  - enable instance to autoload during systemd boot
/etc/init.d/tarantool stop - actually does nothing, just for consistency
systemctl disable tarantool; update-rc.d tarantool remove - disable sysvinit-compatible wrappers

Note that systemctl start tarantool (without @instance) is provided only for interoperability with sysvinit scripts only, please use systemctl start tarantool@instance instead. 
Please refer "Notes for systemd users"  section in our manual for further information.
Distros without systemd are not affected at all.

. Actually this is not a regression.
/etc/tarantool/instances.available contains all available instances managed by tarantoolctl (just by the definition). You can start and stop these instances manually using tarantoolctl start and tarantoolctl stop .
/etc/tarantool/instances.enabled is used by /etc/init.d/tarantool sysvinit script to start instances during system boot. instances.enabled should contains symlinks to instances.available.

. /etc/tarantool/instances.enabled is the only registry of instances used by sysvinit script.
In other words, there is no magic under the hood.  Please stop an instance first and then remove it from /etc.

This behaviour is fixed in systemd configuration (centos 7, fedora, Debian/Ubuntu is coming soon), because systemd tracks started instances somewhere in its internals.
I don't think that a fix of this problem for sysvinit is really important for the project. Sorry.

=> This ticket is a duplicate. # 
Simple UDP echo server
Tarantool currently don't have :func:socket.udp_server(), but this
function can be implemented using sockets and fibers:
```
!/usr/bin/env tarantool
local socket = require('socket')
local errno = require('errno')
local fiber = require('fiber')
local function udp_server_loop(s, handler)
    fiber.name("udp_server")
    while true do
        -- try to read a datagram first
        local msg, peer = s:recvfrom()
        if msg == "" then
            -- socket was closed via s:close()
            break
        elseif msg ~= nil then
            -- got a new datagram
            handler(s, peer, msg)
        else
            if s:errno() == errno.EAGAIN or s:errno() == errno.EINTR then
                -- socket is not ready
                s:readable() -- yield, epoll will wake us when new data arrived
            else
                -- socket error
                local msg = s:error()
                s:close() -- save resources and don't wait GC
                error("Socket error: " .. msg)
            end
        end
    end
end
local function udp_server(host, port, handler)
    local s = socket('AF_INET', 'SOCK_DGRAM', 0)
    if not s then
        return nil -- check errno:strerror()
    end
    if not s:bind(host, port) then
        local e = s:errno() -- save errno
        s:close()
        errno(e) -- restore errno
        return nil -- check errno:strerror()
    end
fiber.create(udp_server_loop, s, handler) -- start a new background fiber
return s

end
```
Usage:
.. code-block:: lua
```
local function handler(s, peer, msg)
    -- You don't have to wait until socket is ready to sent UDP
    -- s:writable()
    s:sendto(peer.host, peer.port, "Pong: " .. msg)
end
local server = udp_server('127.0.0.1', 3548, handler)
if not server then
    error('Failed to bind: ' .. errno.strerror())
end
print('Started')
require('console').start()
```
The example looks a little bit complicated because it actually check
socket errors.

. Needed for Oracle Connector.. fiber_channel has problems with inline functions. The possible solution is to patch extra/apigen to cut everything between curly brackets ({}) for functions:
```
!/bin/sh
sed -n '/^\/** \cond public *\/$/,/^\/** \endcond public *\/$/P'| \
    sed -e '/inline/{:1;N;s/{.*}/;/;T1}'
```
static inline bool
fiber_channel_is_full(struct fiber_channel *ch)
{
        return ch->count >= ch->size;
}
=>
static inline bool
fiber_channel_is_full(struct fiber_channel *ch)
;

host: host
  login: admin

tarantool> uri.parse('admin:@host') <!--  empty password

password: 
  host: host
  login: admin

```
This workaround is unnecessary:

```
index 4e22b04..baa4d84 100644
--- a/src/lua/console.lua
+++ b/src/lua/console.lua

if u.login ~= nil and u.password == nil then
-- Not specifying a password means empty password.
-- Required for passwordless URI forms like admin@host
u.password = ''
end
```

NULL means 'password is not set'. 
'' (empty string) means that user explicitly set empty password.
Please pass MsgPack NULL in case of 'admin@host'.
Tarantool should allow AUTH for  'guest' with NULL password. Currently it is not implemented properly and there is no test case. You can fix this problem too or open a separate ticket.

. There are post-review fixes:

1) NULL has special meaning and semantics in databases. We don't implement this semantics properly, therefore this feature is misleading for most users.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Null_%28SQL%29
Below are comments from @pgulutzan: 
When I have a SCALAR unique non-primary index, I cannot insert nil twice.
I regard this as odd. Is it deliberate?
When I have a SCALAR primary index, I can insert nil.
I regard this as odd. Is it deliberate?
When I have a SCALAR index, the order is: nil, booleans, numbers, strings.
This is wonderful, but is there a reason nil cannot also be in a NUMBER
index?
=>  Please remove nil support for now.

2) INT field type for HASH index
I can create HASH index with 'INT', but there are no test cases for it.
```
tarantool> box.schema.space.create('fieldtypes')
tarantool> box.space.fieldtypes:create_index("primary", { type = 'HASH', parts = { 1, 'INT' }})


unique: true
  parts:
type: INT
    fieldno: 1
  id: 0
  space_id: 513
  name: primary
  type: HASH
...
```

=> Please add tests cases for HASH with INT field type. 

3) non-unique SCALAR, INT and NUMBER indexes
I can't find test cases.
=> Please add tests cases for unique=false with SCALAR, INT, NUMBER types

4) NUMBER field type for HASH index
IEEE 754 floating point values are senseless for HASH index. Exact comparison of two floats is always bad idea. Moreover, it is very easy to create two floats with the same text representation but different binary value.
=> Please forbid NUMBER field type for HASH.

5) SCALAR field type for HASH index
SCALAR has the same problem as NUMBER (see above).
There are three options:
- Keep it as it and add test cases
- Forbid SCALAR field type for HASH index
- Forbid float/double values in HASH index
Let's discuss these options.

. Discussed with @alyapunov and @kostja 
1, 2, 3 OK 
4 and 5: => allow non-unique NUMBER and SCALAR indexes and document that the behavior is implementation defined.

struct PACKED tuple
{
        /*
         * sic: the header of the tuple is used
         * to store a free list pointer in smfree_delayed.
         * Please don't change it without understanding
         * how smfree_delayed and snapshotting COW works.
         */
        /** snapshot generation version */
        uint32_t version;
        /** reference counter */
        uint16_t refs;
        /** format identifier */
        uint16_t format_id;
        /** length of the variable part of the tuple */
        uint32_t bsize;
        /**
         * Fields can have variable length, and thus are packed
         * into a contiguous byte array. Each field is prefixed
         * with MessagePack packed field length.
         */
        char data[0];
};
struct vy_stmt {
        int64_t  lsn;
        uint32_t size;
        uint16_t refs; /* atomic */
        uint8_t  type; /* IPROTO_SELECT/REPLACE/UPSERT/DELETE */
        char data[0];
};
We need 4 more bytes for lsn and one more byte for type to replace struct vy_stmt with struct tuple.

. A spec based on @Gerold103 and @kostja proposals and layout designed by @alyapunov for the new tuple allocator in the former 1.8 branch:
```
struct PACKED tuple {
    / length of the variable part of the tuple */
    uint32_t bsize;
    / reference counter /
    uint16_t refs;
    / format identifier */
    uint16_t format_id;
    / offset of MessagePack array in ->raw /
    uint8_t offset;
    /*
         * Format-specific metadata followed by MessagePack array
         * @sa tuple_meta_memtx
         * @sa tuple_meta_vinyl
         /
    char raw[0];
};
struct PACKED tuple_meta_memtx {
    / snapshot generation version */
    uint32_t version;
    / offsets table - see tuple_format **/
    uint32_t offsets[0];
};
struct PACKED tuple_meta_vinyl {
    / lsn for MVCC */
    int64_t lsn;
    / statement type - IPROTO_SELECT/REPLACE/UPSERT/DELETE */
    int8_t type;
    / offsets table - see tuple_format /
    uint32_t offsets[0];
};
```
Profits:

struct vy_stmt and most vy_stmt wrappers are removed
memtx and vinyl memory levels are completely unified
vinyl can return tuples to IPROTO and Lua without extra copies
this proposal requires just one extra byte in struct tuple

Notes:

a designator of engine (tuple_meta_memtx vs tuple_meta_vinyl) can be stored in struct tuple_format. 
SELECT and DELETE statements doesn't require offsets. Please reserve a special format_id (e.g. 0) to check by assertions.
tuple_meta_vinyl->type can be combined with tuple->format, but it is a trickly, let's try later.
tuple->refs can be extended to 32 bit as @kostja wanted, but it is not mandatory for this ticket.

. 1) cbus has it own thread pool in a thread-local variable:
cbus.c:41: static __thread struct fiber_pool fiber_pool;
2) The fiber-pool uses fiber->state rlist entry to store fibers:
cbus.c:97:  rlist_add_entry(&pool->idle, fiber(), state);
3) cbus's fiber pool is never destroyed:
$ grep -R fiber_pool_destroy .
./cbus.c:fiber_pool_destroy(struct fiber_pool *pool) -- never called
4) cord_destroy() tries to remove fibers from all lists using fiber->state rlist entry
5) cord_destroy() is invoked from the different thread after pthread_join(), so thread-local memory of the cord contains garbage and  fiber->state points to this garbage.
There is no cbus_leave() or something like that so I have no idea where author of this code planned  to call fiber_pool_destroy().  I could add a workaround for this problem, but I want to discuss my WTF questions about this design first. @kostja, please ping me.

struct fiber_pool {
    struct {
        / Cache of fibers which work on incoming messages. */
        struct rlist idle;
        / The number of fibers in the pool. /
        int size;
        / The limit on the number of fibers working on tasks. */
        int max_size;
        /
         * Fibers in leave the pool if they have nothing to do

        /* Staged messages (for fibers to work on) /

     */
    struct ev_async fetch_output;
    /** The lock around the pipe. */
    pthread_mutex_t mutex;
    /** The pipe with incoming messages. */
    struct stailq pipe;
} __attribute__((aligned(CACHELINE_SIZE)));

};

. The same thing for range->begin and range->end:
```
static int
vy_write_range_header(int fd, struct vy_range *range)
{
    struct vy_range_info info;
    off_t offset = sizeof(info);
memset(&info, 0, sizeof(info));

if (range->begin) {
    if (vy_pwrite_file(fd, range->begin->data,
               range->begin->size, offset) < 0)
        return -1;
    info.begin_key_offset = offset;
    info.begin_key_size = range->begin->size;
    offset += range->begin->size;
}
if (range->end) {
    if (vy_pwrite_file(fd, range->end->data,
               range->end->size, offset) < 0)
        return -1;
    info.end_key_offset = offset;
    info.end_key_size = range->end->size;
    offset += range->end->size;
}

```

        fiber.sleep(0)

    ch:put(true)
end

end

end

File Dependencies
RPM gives you the ability to depend on files instead of packages. Whenever possible you should avoid file dependencies as they slow down dependency resolution and require the package manager to download file lists in addition to to regular dependency information. There are, however, times when other technical considerations outweigh these considerations. If the files you need are prone to moving between packages of different names, it can be useful to depend on those files directly.

. The primary problem that there is no way to use some key in memtx space for autoincrement  because 1.7.x doesn't have cross-engine transactions in 1.7.x (see #1958).  Moreover, even with the proposed new cross-engine transaction manager such types of transactions will be aborted by conflicts due to limitations of the transaction manager. Kostja suggests to implement autonomous transactions and perform this increment outside of the calling transaction. 
From https://oracle-base.com/articles/misc/autonomous-transactions:

Autonomous transactions allow you to leave the context of the calling transaction, perform an independent transaction, and return to the calling transaction without affecting it's state. The autonomous transaction has no link to the calling transaction, so only commited data can be shared by both transactions.

Since active transaction is currently bounded to the fiber, I have no idea how to implement two or more simultaneous transactions in the same fiber. This ticket is complicated and requires significant research.. ```

. Moved to 1.7.3 after discussion with @kostja. @locker is already working on the new metadata storage, needed for backups.. Some fresh ideas:

Add tarantoolctl <instance> backup <path to> and tarantoolctl <instance> restore <path from> commands
tarantoolctl backup prepares the list of files, print cp -p <files> and then runs this script via shell.
tarantoolctl backup --dry-run prints command cp -p <files> command line without running them
tarantoolctl backup | sometool print the list of files into stdout and waits for EOF on pipe.
tarantoolctl <instance> restore <dir> checks that instances is not started and its data directory is empty and then copies files from <dir>.

rsync can be used instead  of "cp -p" to display the progress interactively.. Done. 🥇

. 1.7.3-269-g4c520cf. => 1.7.4. Blocked by #2312. Duplicate of #389. => 1.7.4. Implemented by  39c21a7e3e753f74f495546a42d0aaf227874e25. Lua implementation by @Boiler:
```
local log = require('log')
local fiber = require('fiber')
local socket = require('socket')
if sd_fiber ~= nil then
    fiber.kill(sd_fiber:id())
    log.info("sd_fiber killed")
end
sd_fiber = nil
local sd_sock_path = os.getenv("NOTIFY_SOCKET")
if sd_sock_path == nil then
    sd_sock_path = "/run/systemd/notify"
end
if sd_sock_path ~= nil then
    sd_fiber = fiber.create(function()
        fiber.self():name('sd_notify')
        local sd_sock = socket('AF_UNIX', 'SOCK_DGRAM', 0)
        sd_sock:sysconnect('unix/', sd_sock_path)
        if sd_sock ~= nil then
            sd_sock:write("READY=1")
            log.info("systemd notified")
            fiber.sleep(3) -- waiting for box
            while true do
                local str = box.info.status .. " ; quota_usage: " .. string.format("%.2f", 100 / (box.slab.info().quota_size / box.slab.info().quota_used)) .. "%"
                if box.info.replication.status ~= 'off' then
                    str = str .. " ; repl_status: " .. box.info.replication.status .. ", lag: " .. string.format("%.2f", box.info.replication.lag)
                end
                sd_sock:write("STATUS=" .. str)
                fiber.sleep(1)
            end
        end
    end)
end
```

memtx.memory is overall limit both for indexes and data.

wal.rescan_delay is better read as wal.rescan_delay_seconds

. > logger.pipe will be more obvious if named logger.pipe_to_cmd
It is not clear now if options in logger are mutually exclusive. If
it's possible to configure multiple loggers at the same time, it will
be useful to be able to specify different logging levels for each logger.
If not, an explicit logger.engine option is required, and other options
should be prefixed by logging engine type. E.g. logger.pipe_cmd,
logger.syslog_identity, logger.syslog_facility.

. Fixed by #940. . We discussed this feature with @GeorgyKirichenko today and realized that it can't be implemented easily in the current replication architecture. Tarantool creates a hashmap of replicas on box.cfg() using replica_uuid from greeting. Received UUID is used as a primary key to identify replicas in the replicaset, so it can't be changed without reconstructing replicaset by box.cfg(). 
Suggested workaround is to call box.cfg { replication = ""} and then box.cfg { replication = { list of replicas }} to re-build replicaset. . Rolling => 1.7.5. How is it supposed to work? box.info.WHAT? Please elaborate your proposal.

Vinyl doesn't abort a transaction at fiber yield. But the same fiber may serve different connections of the binary protocol. It means that queries from different connections may end up in the same transaction, or that a subsequent query which is intended for a multi-statement transaction ends up committed prematurely.
 It means that queries from different connections may end up in the same transaction

struct vclock has 32 bit unsigned int map used to speed up comparison and iteration over vclock
struct vclock is statically allocated and huge values of VCLOCK_MAX may cause stack overlow
Replication relay is not optimized for the large number of replicas, see #1270

Please try to deal with the first problem before increasing VCLOCK_MAX limit.

Pushed as 1.7.3-273-g6cc47f6. Thanks for the patch and your feedback.. Fixed  by 83a16be1eabb2f7f31503b81848aa691d5430718. 1.7.4-318-gb1cb4a1f3. 1.6.9-83-g7a0996c5a. 1.7.4-151-g7e62ac79b. The code above is misleading, but correct. I re-checked man pages:
Linux
From pthread_getattr_np(3):

pthread_getattr_np() initializes the thread attributes object referred to by attr.

From pthread_attr_init(3)

  Calling pthread_attr_init() on a thread attributes object that has already been initialized results in undefined behavior.


I understand these sentences as  "pthread_getattr_np() MUST NOT be preceded by  pthread_attr_init() call". 
From pthread_getattr_np(3):

When   the   thread  attributes  object  returned  by  pthread_getattr_np()  is  no  longer  required,  it  should  be  destroyed  using pthread_attr_destroy(3)

=>
pthread_attr_t thread_attr;
    pthread_getattr_np(cord->id, &thread_attr);
    pthread_attr_getstack(&thread_attr, &cord->sched.coro.stack,
                          &cord->sched.coro.stack_size);
    pthread_attr_destroy(&thread_attr);
BSD
See pthread_attr_get_np(3)

The pthread_attr_get_np() function   is used to get existent thread's
     attributes.  Itis HIGHLY RECOMMENDED to use pthread_attr_init(3) function to allocate
     attribute storage.

=> 
pthread_attr_t thread_attr;
    pthread_attr_init(&thread_attr);
    pthread_attr_get_np(pid, &attr);
    pthread_attr_getstack(&thread_attr, &cord->sched.coro.stack,
                          &cord->sched.coro.stack_size);
    pthread_attr_destroy(&thread_attr);
macOS
There are neither pthread_attr_get_np() nor pthread_getattr_np().
=>
cord->sched.coro.stack_size = pthread_get_stacksize_np(cord->id);
    cord->sched.coro.stack = pthread_get_stackaddr_np(cord->id);
I refactored this piece of code in the foolproof way:
```
diff --git a/src/fiber.c b/src/fiber.c
index 7b67ec6..cf5d44f 100644
--- a/src/fiber.c
+++ b/src/fiber.c
@@ -739,13 +739,20 @@ cord_create(struct cord cord, const char name)
    /* Record stack extents */

#if (HAVE_PTHREAD_GET_STACKSIZE_NP && HAVE_PTHREAD_GET_STACKADDR_NP)
+       / macOS /
        cord->sched.coro.stack_size = pthread_get_stacksize_np(cord->id);
        cord->sched.coro.stack = pthread_get_stackaddr_np(cord->id);
-#elif (HAVE_PTHREAD_GETATTR_NP || HAVE_PTHREAD_ATTR_GET_NP)
+#elif HAVE_PTHREAD_ATTR_GET_NP
+       / BSD /
        pthread_attr_t thread_attr;
-#if HAVE_PTHREAD_ATTR_GET_NP
        pthread_attr_init(&thread_attr);
-#endif
+       pthread_attr_get_np(pid, &attr);
+       pthread_attr_getstack(&thread_attr, &cord->sched.coro.stack,
+                             &cord->sched.coro.stack_size);
+       pthread_attr_destroy(&thread_attr);
+#elif HAVE_PTHREAD_GETATTR_NP
+       / Linux /
+       pthread_attr_t thread_attr;
        pthread_getattr_np(cord->id, &thread_attr);
        pthread_attr_getstack(&thread_attr, &cord->sched.coro.stack,
                              &cord->sched.coro.stack_size);
diff --git a/src/trivia/config.h.cmake b/src/trivia/config.h.cmake
index db1368d..1c2731e 100644
--- a/src/trivia/config.h.cmake
+++ b/src/trivia/config.h.cmake
@@ -181,10 +181,6 @@
 #cmakedefine HAVE_PTHREAD_GETATTR_NP 1
 #cmakedefine HAVE_PTHREAD_ATTR_GET_NP 1
-#if defined(HAVE_PTHREAD_ATTR_GET_NP)
-#define pthread_getattr_np pthread_attr_get_np
-#endif
-
 #cmakedefine HAVE_PTHREAD_GET_STACKSIZE_NP 1
 #cmakedefine HAVE_PTHREAD_GET_STACKADDR_NP 1
``` 
I can push the patch if you wish. I have no idea how to implement common pthread_getattr_np()/pthread_attr_getstack() API for all platforms. Thus part of POSIX has been completely screwed up by guys from GNU, BSD and Apple.. ./sysdeps/nptl/pthread.h from glibc 2.2.4:
```
/ Initialize thread attribute ATTR with attributes corresponding to the
   already running thread TH.  It shall be called on uninitialized ATTR
   and destroyed with pthread_attr_destroy when no longer needed.  /
extern int pthread_getattr_np (pthread_t __th, pthread_attr_t __attr)
     __THROW __nonnull ((2));
endif
```

It shall be called on uninitialized ATTR and destroyed with pthread_attr_destroy when no longer needed

I'll patch fiber.cc to remove #ifdefs from the code.. pthread_getattr_np() + pthread_attr_destroy() combination is totally broken on Glibc 2.12 (RHELL 6.x).
Please forget about ASAN on this platform.

Meta-Commands
Anything you enter in console that begins with an unquoted backslash is a console meta-command that is processed by console itself. These commands make console more useful for administration or scripting. Meta-commands are often called slash or backslash commands.
The format of a console command is the backslash, followed immediately by a command verb, then any arguments. The arguments are separated from the command verb and each other by any number of whitespace characters.
1.8.0

\q[uit] - quit interactive console (pgsql, mysql)
\h[elp] or \? - display help
\c[onnect] uri -  connect to remote server
\s[et] lang[uage] sql or \set lang lua - change the current language
\s[et] delim[iter] ; or \s[et] delim[iter] "$EOF" or  \s[et] delim[iter]" - set statement delimiter
\s[et] autocompletion on; or \s[et] completion off;  - enable/disable autocompletion.

Limitations for the first version:

SQL language outputs results in YAML format, we will change it by the next patches.
SQL language doesn't support auto-completion, we will decide how to add it later.

. This feature is not "breaking change", but it needed for the customer  => 1.7.4. ### Proposal

Extend all requests with optional keyword arguments: 

conn.space:insert(tuple)  => :insert(tuple[, opts]) 
conn.space:replace(tuple) => :replace(tuple[, opts])
conn.space.name.index:get(key) => :get(key[, opts])
conn.space.name.index:select(key[, opts]) => no changes
conn.space.name.index:delete(key) => :delete(key[, opts])
conn.space.name.index:update(key, expr) => :update(key, expr[, opts])
conn.space.name.index:upsert(key[, expr]) => :upsert(key[[, expr], opts])

Add a new per-request option buffer = <ibuf object>:

conn.space.name.index:select(key, { buffer = <ibuf object> })


If buffer option is set then net.box skips msgpack.decode() on xrow->body and copies (memcpy()) entire  xrow->body directly to <ibuf object>. The buffer is not truncated before copying. The number of written bytes is returned from :requestname() functions.  


{ buffer = nil } case is not changed and continues to return Lua tables as results.


Error handling is not changed in both cases.


We already have unofficial internal bindings to struct ibuf - see require('buffer').
Alternative: copy only xrow->body[IPROTO_DATA] instead of just entire xrow->body.

A follow up enhancement. Add timeout option to all requests and deprecate weird :timeout(): construction:

conn:timeout(<timeout>).space:insert(tuple) => conn.space.insert(tuple, { timeout = <timeout> })
Reasonable
Raw MessagePack output is needed  to workaround buggy GC in LuaJIT. For example, space:select(key, { limit = 100000}) may create 100000 cdata objects and kill LuaJIT by finalizers limit.  
@Sulverus will be able to implement C function in tarantool/shard to merge multiple <ibuf> without producing Lua garbage.
Pros


This change is easy to implement and backward-compatible.


This proposal doesn't violate encapsulation of net.box and doesn't require merging of tarantool/shard into net.box and vice versa. 


I plan to extended require('buffer') as a replacement of slow Lua strings. For example, buffer can be used to implement encoding/decoding of raw types in MessagePack. socket module already supports buffer in some functions.


opts can be used of other options in the future


Cons
Current API of conn:call() and conn:eval() can't be extended with opts table:
conn:call(funcname, arg1, arg2, arg3, ...)
conn:eval(expr, arg1, arg2, arg3, ...)
Possible solutions:


Don't extend call() and eval() with opts and ignore problem for now.  Obviously :timeout: can't be deprecated in this case.


Wrap arguments into Lua table (a breaking change):


conn:call(funcname, arg1, arg2, arg3, ...) => conn:call(funcname, {arg1, arg2, arg3, ... }[, opts]) 
conn:eval(expr, arg1, arg2, arg3, ...)  => conn:eval(expr, {arg1, arg2, arg3, ... }[, opts])
Please note that net.box already wraps ... into {...} under the hood:
```
function remote_methods:call_16(func_name, ...)
    remote_check(self, 'call')
    return self:_request('call_16', tostring(func_name), {...})
end
function remote_methods:call(func_name, ...)
    remote_check(self, 'call')
    return unpack(self:_request('call_17', tostring(func_name), {...}))
end
```
{...} breaks JIT traces, but we already know that LuaJIT doesn't have real JIT.
ANyway, call(name, arg1, arg2, ...) is very conventional syntax. Builtin pcall() has the same syntax.

The same as 2, but use existing call_16 per-connection option to switch between old and new API:

net.box:connect(host, port, {call_16 = true}):call(funcname, arg1, arg2, ...)
net.box:connect(host, port):call(funcname, {arg1, arg2, ...}, opts)
We have already broken call() in 1.7.x, so call_16 is not big deal.

Add new functions:

conn:xcall(funcname, {arg1, arg2, arg3, ...}[, opts]) 
conn:xeval(expr, {arg1, arg2, arg3, ...}[, opts]))
I have no idea how to name these functions.

Put opts table as the first argument:

conn:call({ name = <funcname>, timeout = <timeout>, buffer = <buffer>}, arg1, arg2, arg3, ...) 
conn:eval({ expr = <expr>, timeout = <timeout>, buffer = <buffer>}, arg1, arg2, arg3, ...)

Discard the first part of my proposal and  continue in :timeout: style:

conn:opts({timeout = <timeout>, buffer = <buffer>}.space:select(). @mejedi said that (4) is better than (6), but we need to find some better name than "call_ex".
. > There's another issue @rtsisyk didn't mention. Currently, :select() argument is optional. Adding options create an ambiguity: how to treat :select() with 1 argument?
select(key) should be handled as select(key, {})
. > Troubles with current implementation shouldn't bother us in API redesign.
We can (and should) use :opts construction like these:

nb_object = net.box:connect('host:port')
nb_wrapper = nb_object:opts()
nb_wrapper:select(...)
nb_wrapper:insert(...)

Let's take a look on our real problem:
```
local ibuf = require('buffer').ibuf
nb_object = net.box:connect('host:port')
nb_wrapper = nb_object:opts({ buffer = ibuf, timeout = 100500 })
ibuf:reset()
nb_wrapper:select(key)
handle_raw_msgpack(ibuf.rpos, ibuf.wpos)
ibuf:reset()
nb_wrapper:insert(tuple)
handle_raw_msgpack(ibuf.rpos, ibuf.wpos)
```
vs
```
local ibuf = require('buffer').ibuf
nb = net.box:connect('host:port')
ibuf:reset()
nb_wrapper:select(key, { buffer = ibuf, timeout = 100500 })
handle_raw_msgpack(ibuf.rpos, ibuf.wpos)
ibuf:reset()
nb_wrapper:insert(tuple, { buffer = ibuf, timeout = 100500 })
handle_raw_msgpack(ibuf.rpos, ibuf.wpos)
```
In the second example per-request arguments are explicitly passed per request. It is so obvious that per-request arguments are per-request arguments, isn't it? I have no idea why buffer, which is an in-out argument to request, should be stored somewhere in a global state (nb_wrapper). The first example is simple more error-prone than the second one, especially for our buffer case.
I vote for conn:call(name, {arg1, arg2, arg3, ...}, {opts}) with call_v16 per-connection option for compatibility:

The second example above looks more natural for me, because the request parameters are actually request parameters.
I agree with @mejedi that :timeout: implementation is a mess and there is no way to fix it.
varargs to conn:call(name, ...) are implicitly packed to a Lua table under the hood and this operation is very inefficient in LuaJIT.
conn:call(name, arg, nil, arg2, nil) doesn't work as expected and it can't be fixed in any efficient way.
We already transformed box.replace(space_id, part1, part, part3, ...) to space:replace({part1, part2, part3, ...}) somewhere  in the past and I have no motivation to keep legacy non-extendable call() API.
CALL has already been broken in 1.7.x and the most 1.6.x users will need call_v16 per-option to migrate.

. Caused by 
```
commit 8116f2096fefdbda9684dbc1f5194d7038bd1b8a
Author: Vladimir Davydov vdavydov.dev@gmail.com
Date:   Wed Apr 5 18:32:01 2017 +0300
vinyl: pin in-memory trees on tx prepare

Pin each in-memory tree which is going to be modified by a transaction
on Engine::prepare, unpin it on commit or rollback. Pinned in-memory
trees can't be dumped until they are unpinned - dump/compaction task
constructors wait until pin_count drops to 0 before handing the task
over to a worker thread. Since the constructors rotate the in-memory
tree before waiting and new transaction can only go to active in-memory
trees, they won't wait forever, only until all transactions that were
started before the task was scheduled are over.

Some admin commands, like IPROTO_JOIN and IPROTO_SUBSCRIBE can't be mixed with other DML requests, like  IPROTO_REPLACE, IPROTO_DELETE and others. The reason IPROTO_JOIN/IPROTO_SUBSCRIBE can't multiplexed is just technical - we transfer client's fd to a separate thread to send snapshots and xlogs from the disk. Due to fact that even our replication client doesn't need SYNC value, I don't think this problem is very important for us. Anyway,  pull requests && patches are always welcome :)

. It seems that error(x, 2) trick doesn't work in our case. All Lua API is implemented via FFI or Lua/C. C API creates a struct error object for every error, sets it into a global errno-like variable (struct diag) and returns -1. Both FFI and Lua/C calls C API, checks for -1, gets precreated struct error object and re-throws it to the upper levels as CDATA. Upper levels (IPROTO_CALL, IPROTO_EVAL, console, triggers, fiber.create()) extracts original struct error from Lua and saves back to our errno (struct diag). In this scheme any information added by Lua is simple discarded.
This problem can only be solved by adding tracebacks to struct error. I've updated https://github.com/tarantool/tarantool/issues/677 and attached code we made during investigation of this ticket.

. This problem is caused by usage of slab_map() by lsregion_alloc(). slab_map() allocates slabs of size arena->slab_size (4mb by default), therefore lsregion can't allocate chunks larger than slab_size bytes. 
Possible solutions:

Use malloc() for huge chunks in lsregion, like in slab_cache. Caveats: it will duplicate slab_get() logic from slab_cache().
Switch to slab_cache() in lsregion, like it was done in the first version of lsregion.
Create a separate arena for vinyl with configurable slab_size. Caveats:  huge slab_size is ineffective.

. Moving to 1.7.6 together with #934 . Unfortunately, this idea doesn't work.  We tried two different approaches to do that and both of them have failed:
a) Override malloc()/free() globally by defining malloc()/free()/realloc()/calloc() symbols somewhere inside Tarantool binary. This is technically possible, because malloc()/free()/realloc()/calloc() are declared as week symbols in libc and LD will prefer our symbols instead of system's.  Problem: malloc() is used by internal allocations by libc which can happen before main() and before initialization of memory/quota/fiber subsystem. Checking for this case on every malloc/free can be expensive.
b) Override malloc()/free()/realloc()/calloc() symbols using --Wl,-wrap,SYMBOL DL feature works. In this case libc continue to use original malloc of internal purposes, but all sources files in src and third/party use our wrapper. This approach has failed because there are a lot of functions in libc(), like strdup(), which allocates memory using libc's malloc and then this memory are freed by our wrapped free(), which causes negative quota. Patch attached. We can backport the fix from luarocks 3.0:  https://github.com/luarocks/luarocks/commit/e620a7e022c019ece6419446e6220d424aff9b42. 1.7.4-435-g0905310e1. 1.7.4-301-gef7a350a9. . http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec4.html#sec4.2

Multiple message-header fields with the same field-name MAY be present in a message if and only if the entire field-value for that header field is defined as a comma-separated list [i.e., #(values)]. It MUST be possible to combine the multiple header fields into one "field-name: field-value" pair, without changing the semantics of the message, by appending each subsequent field-value to the first, each separated by a comma. The order in which header fields with the same field-name are received is therefore significant to the interpretation of the combined field value, and thus a proxy MUST NOT change the order of these field values when a message is forwarded.

From pipe(7):
   POSIX.1 says that write(2)s of less than PIPE_BUF bytes must be atomic:
  the output data is written to the pipe as a contiguous sequence. Writes
  of more than PIPE_BUF bytes may be nonatomic: the kernel may interleave
  the data with data written by other processes. PIPE_BUF is 4k on Linux.
Nevertheless, let's ignore the fact that messages can be interleaved in

. Added replication_quorum option to box.cfg():

box.cfg { replication = {xx, yy, zz}, replication_quorum = 0 } - don't wait replicas (old 1.6 behaviour)
box.cfg {  replication = {xx, yy, zz, replication_quorum = 100500} - wait all replicas (new 1.7 behaviour)
box.cfg {  replication = {xx, yy, zz, replication_quorum = N} - wait N replicas (custom logic)

Proposed logic with replication_lag + read_only on box.cfg() doesn't solve the problem that replica can fall behind master AFTER box.cfg(). The comprehensive solution is needed to forbid read/write queries on stale replicas. Currently this logic can be implemented using Lua without patching server.

From PostgreSQL documentation:

Row-level triggers fired BEFORE can return null to signal the trigger manager to skip the rest of the operation for this row (i.e., subsequent triggers are not fired, and the INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE does not occur for this row). If a nonnull value is returned then the operation proceeds with that row value. Returning a row value different from the original value of NEW alters the row that will be inserted or updated. Thus, if the trigger function wants the triggering action to succeed normally without altering the row value, NEW (or a value equal thereto) has to be returned. To alter the row to be stored, it is possible to replace single values directly in NEW and return the modified NEW, or to build a complete new record/row to return. In the case of a before-trigger on DELETE, the returned value has no direct effect, but it has to be nonnull to allow the trigger action to proceed. Note that NEW is null in DELETE triggers, so returning that is usually not sensible. The usual idiom in DELETE triggers is to return OLD.. Serious problem, should be in 1.7.7. ```

In MongoDB there is a feature called capped collections which
are fixed-size lists that support high-throughput operations
that insert, retrieve, and delete values based on insertion
order.
It is really nice feature that can be used in

logging window that shows last X logs
most X recent active users in a time windows (do not to store them all)
last X activities
Newest articles in the front page

Is there any efficient way to do it in Tarantool/Box?

Our basic principle is that we try to teach people to fish,
rather than giving them a fish :)
There are at least a couple of ways to do a capped collection in
Tarantool, depending on your average collection size.
If average collection size is small, say 5-10 elements, it's best
to map a single collection to a single Tarantool tuple. There are
push and pop operations on tuple, so you can append fields
at the end of a tuple, and pop them from the beginning or at a
given field index. Multiple tuple operations can be combined and
are executed atomically in a single UPDATE.
If average collection size is bigger than a few dozen elements,
it's better to map a single collection to a single space, and wrap
space change operations into stored procedures. 
To get an idea how this could be done, please take a look at 
box.auto_increment() implementation:
https://github.com/tarantool/tarantool/blob/master/src/box/lua/misc.lua#L55
The reason it becomes more efficient is that tarantool tuples
are immutable and are never updated in place, and this takes its
toll when average tuple size grows beyond a few kilobytes.
There is also a queue module for tarantool, it turns tarantool into
a queue server, it can also be of interest:
https://github.com/tarantool/queue/blob/master/init.lua

http://tarantool.org - an efficient, extensible in-memory data store

There is no single command line option which can be set in the configuration file, and vice versa. 
This avoids a lot of ambiguity in monitoring and spares people from extra headache, where the current server option
came from.
To support external scripts, we need to come up with a include() directive for configuration files, or some other solution.
In 1.6 we can switch to lua for config, and thus get require('/path/to/config/piece.lua') for free.
If that's an OK solution, it can be done.

. ## Bootstrap
- check command line options, handle argc, argv in the following way:
  if there is no shebang, handle --version --help, and exit
  if there is shebang, check and open the file. Prepare
  argc/argv to pass to shebang.
--verbose option is gone
  --cfg-check option is gone, since there is no formal "config"
  any more
  --cfg option is gone too
- initialize fiber, lua and other runtime and other infrastructure and
  fire off a fiber that will execute shebang. 
This introduces a notion of "core" modules, which are config-less
  and always available.
So we have always available:
fiber, socket, ipc modules (the list could be continued).
This raiases a quiestion: what namespace do they occupy, where do they
  reside if they are always available?
  It's nice to leave 'box' namespace only available for storage,
  which needs to be started separately.
- when shebang ends, check if there are events. if there
  are no events, exit, otherwise continue the event loop.
Within shebang provide the following facilities:
- app server initialization:
(available without any extra require)
box.background(
    { username = name, 
      workdir = dir,
      pid_file = pid_file, 
      logger = logger
      log_level = ...
      logger_nonblock = true
      coredump = true/false
      custom_proc_title = ?
    }
  )
This function can be called only once.
  It sets appropriate members of box.info:
  box.info.pid_file
box.info.username
box.info.logger
box.info.logger_pid
QQQ: should we rename box.info to something different?
  QQQ: should the missing options of the app server appear
  there?
- box initialization:
box.recover(
    {
     replication_source = , 
     too_long_threshold = ,
     memtx = {
         slab_alloc_arena = ,
         slab_alloc_minimal= ,
         slab_alloc_factor = ,
     }
     wal =  {
        mode = snap_dir = ,
        fsync_delay = 
        rows_per_wal = 
        panic_on_error = 
        rescan_delay = 
        snap_io_rate_limit = 
     }
     -- note: local_hot_standby is gone, it's always on
    }
  )
Once box.recover is done, all these options are available in
  box.cfg, and some of them are settable (via setindex hook).
  box.recover() can be called only once
- admin and iproto are protocols, which can be initialized
  and destoryed any time, in any number of instances.
  box.recover() sets box_process hook and this is how they check
  that they can be available.
iproto options are: bind ip addr and port
  amdin options are: bind ip addr and port
- to help initialize box/app server there is a helper function
  box.load_cfg(path). It returns a Lua table back, where path
  points to a Lua script, defining tables:
tarantool = {
      coredump = true
  }
  box = {
      memtx = {
          slab_alloc_arena = 3
      }
  }
So a typical shebang script looks like:
local cfg = box.load_cfg("my.cfg")
box.background(cfg.tarantool)
box.recover(cfg.box)
box.iproto.start(cfg.iproto)
box.admin.start(cfg.admin)
The above lines are available in a function called
box.quickstart().
It searches for a config file called tarantool.cfg in the current
directory, then /etc, and uses it to initialize tarantool.

. Without a config file, we need a dynamically growing arena. This is not implemented.
What's the provisioning against a DBA mistake, when the server silently starts without a config file, whereas the opposite was intended? This patch will introduce a lot of silent mistakes into DBAs everyday work.
What's the provisioning against starting multiple instances in the same data directory without "seeing" each other and corrupting the data directory or behaving in unpredictable ways?
What is the use case this patch is trying to solve? Ease of use? Doesn't help, typically one starts/stops the server with 'service start/service stop', so doesn't operate with configuration file directly. Scripting? For scripting, it's perhaps safer to start with wal_mode = none. 
Overall, before writing a patch, it would be nice to see a spec for this feature describing its use and all the corner cases it introduces.
A few comments also about the rationale for writing the patch:

The feature will simplify testing and development process and reduce the barrier to entry for newcomers. It is also needed for #124.

How exactly? And no, the way this feature is implemented is not needed at all for #124: what we do in interpreter mode can be completely different from what we do in the daemon mode, it can even be a different program.
The way to go
For #124, we may assume some defaults in the interpreter mode, and require an explicit path to snapshot file in box.snapshot(). We also need a dynamic arena first, otherwise this patch is useless. If we want this patch for the daemon mode, we need an explicit option, something like --skip-defaults, to skip looking for the configuration file. 
BTW: what does Redis have to do with it? Neither MySQL nor Postgres nor any other mature DBMS can start without a configuration file. Why did you choose Redis? Besides, this option is necessary for the app server, not for the database.

. Before require runs a chunk, it defines a global variable _REQUIREDNAME containing the virtual name of the file being required. We can use these facilities to extend the functionality of require. In an extreme example, we may set the path to something like "/usr/local/lua/newrequire.lua", so that every call to require runs newrequire.lua, which can then use the value of _REQUIREDNAME to actually load the required file.

. The bug is in the new btree index implementation. bps_tree stores a pointer to Index::key_def in iterator structe and a s context in bps_tree_create(). ALTER in case of RENAME simply replaces the old key def with a new, keeping the old index. This makes it possble to rename an index without a full rebuild. However, the remembered reference still points to the old key def, which is freed.
. Fixed by changing the way alter updates the index.

. It seems we need two functions, all available to any user: 
- one maps object name to object id. It is a quick one:
  box.schema.oid(type, name) - looks things up in the data dictionary
- another indeed to list available grants; 
Auto-granting access to these functions seems to be a flawed design idea - better support (albeit limited) roles right from start. This way access to these and other functions can be granted to PUBLIC role in a managed way. And PUBLIC role is then auto-granted to every existing user. Recursive grants with roles don't need to be supported, and without recursive grants supporting roles doesn't seem to be too difficult.

. @rtsisyk , your analysis of the problem is wrong. The server correctly receves the signal in the event loop, and begins terminating the loop. It has time to shut down properly. The problem is that we don't interrupt recovery properly in this case, so the file is left open withuot a eof marker. We need to fix sigterm-based shutdown to close the file the same way it's closed in daemon mode.

. Peter, I didn't understand @rtsisyk explanation, so I asked him.
Here's the deal:
- in 1.5, the multi-line feature would concatenate multiple lines into one. So it would "help" you transform an otherwise invalid Lua into a valid Lua
- in 1.5, the multi-line feature preserves the input as is, and passes it to Lua. This is necessary, for example, to report line numbers in error messages correctly.
So, when in 1.5 the interpreter didn't see \n, in 1.6 it gets them as is. But an unescaped \n is not allowed inside a Lua literal, hence a syntax error.
If you transform your example to:
dostring('return ...',
1, 2, 3)!
Things should start working again.

. Peter,
this is a strange artifact of console implementation.
Here's what happens: 
when you issue 'console.connect()' and connect to a port, and then invoke f1() or f2(), you actually invoke "eval" binary protocol command, which, in turn, evaluates an arbitrary Lua expresssion you pass to it, in your example, "return f1()" or "return f2()".
setuid user change only works when a function is invoked with CALL binary protocol command, so if you change your client code to:
```
tarantool> c = remote.new('3301')

...
tarantool> c:call('f2')




[0]
...
tarantool> c:call('f1')





error: Read access denied for user 'guest' to space '_func'
```

the code works as expected. 
Actually, it doesn't. There was a bug with that code path too, but I will fix it now, before you get to read this message.
So I wonder if it's possible to document this artifact in the documentation for console? 
You could perhaps say that in console, you can't expect setuid functions to work, since console always communicates with the server by way of passing an expression to execute, and as long as the server executes the expression, it can't know if it is necessary to change user id for some functions within it.

. A possible way to fix:
- always fork before initializing coeio. Set up pipes/redirection to redirect stdin/stdout to a child.
- if background option is set in box.cfg{}, exit from the parent process, which was attached to the terminal.
  Alternatively, let the parent hang around so that it can work as a spawner/waitpid manager so that we can implement coio_*(fork/exec), popen in our API. We need fork/exec/popen for instance management, which is in turn necessary for automatic failover/replica reprovisioning and automatic testing.
It's best if this code is put into a library wiith a standard api in src/lib, and this library can be used by any fat process which needs to be able to daemonize/fork/exec and can't fork itself.
+1 to this way to fix: we need to implement automatic restart on crash as a server option, and it's only possible if the guardian process is created at once at start up.
Other stuff related to this problem:
- just like nginx, support n_instances configuration option, which defines how many instances of the script to create (to support sharding out of the box)
- this is also necessary to implement pipe() command in Lua (or make os.execute() non-blocking and non-forking the entire database instance).

Original issue as reported in the very first message was about fork breaking fibers sheduling on FreeBSD (sample code never makes it through to the "after server" line).
This happens because libev REQUIRES certain actions to keep the event loop operational after fork. This is because kqueue has a super weird fork semantics and has to be recreated after fork.
The fix: https://github.com/tarantool/tarantool/commits/gh-517

. In the end we return a Lua table with all triggers.
. When you define a trigger, you get back an object which can be used to later on clear or reset this trigger. In theory the type of that object should not interest you, but it happens to be a Lua function which you passed in. In Lua a function is a first-class object. So, yes, instead of a numeric identifier, we return a handle - Lua function. Invoking the trigger-definition function (on_* function) with no arguments lists all triggers, i.e. returns handles of all trigger objects. We had a discussion internally when approaching the implementation, and decided to do it this way. Please document this, or, if you feel it's a bad solution, share what problems you see with it.

. Now, this patch, unfortunately, needs to be re-done. The feature request wasn't specified  well enough.
We need to look around and see what others do too, before coming back to this.
First of all, the user needs to see a single entry for a single node. I.e. if we have both a relay and a remote in a master-master setting, we need to display only 1 entry in replication status table.
Second, in case of multi-source, we need to find a way to index the output A quick index is needed so that we can display state of 1 replica only, without building an entire table. Apparently we need to index it with server ids (short ones). Perhaps we need to enforce human-readable names on nodes, and index the table using these names.
Finally, we need to find a way to merge information from outgoing vclock (remote->vlcock) and incoming vclock (relay->vclock), as well as from outgoing lag and incoming lag into few comprehensible metrics. 
How much is the remote behind and how much are we behind? We have the following data:
- the time when we sent the last row to remote (idle1)
- the time when we received last row from remote (idle2)
- the timestamp of the last row received
- the timestamp of the last row sent.
Can we assume that link speed is uniform, and merge two idle times and two lag times and display the min (idle1, idle2) as idle, and min(lag1, lag2) as lag? I think we need to find a way to do it, since that's what the user is interested in. Making sense of two idle and two lag times is difficult even to us, not to mention users. 
Finally, we need to find a way to merge vclocks. We actually have 3 vclocks to sync: recovery->vclock, remote->vclock, relay->vclock. In a totally synchronous system, all vclocks are identical. So, if they are not, the difference tells us about events which have not reached the other side yet. So, perhaps we need to print a single vclock in the following form:
{ 1: 32 (+3), 2: 33 (-3) }, showing how much the master is ahead or behind the replica.
Last thing, we need to replace socket address with uri from the configuration file. Addresses and ports are useful, but take a lot of display space, and are perhaps useful for debugging, but not at all handy if one just needs to monitor replciation and do health checks. 
Something to consider: 
http://galeracluster.com/documentation-webpages/monitoringthecluster.html
https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/replication-multi-source-monitoring.html
http://docs.continuent.com/tungsten-replicator-2.2/operations-status.html
. Galera uses node names in configuration:
http://galeracluster.com/documentation-webpages/dbconfiguration.html
Needs to be checked whether or not a node name is mandatory. Without names, the whole thing can become messy pretty easily.
. Example where you need to check separately master and slave status:
https://code.google.com/p/tungsten-replicator/wiki/Cheat_Sheet
I think it's a bad idea - all the user cares about is divergence of master and slave, we should not be forcing him/her to merge master and slave status to find it out.

. Let me clarify. Right now, to avoid double definition of spaces, users, grants, as well as conflicts between master script and a replica script, developers have to add if_not_exists = true clause to all grants, create/drop space, etc. 
Plus, to avoid conflict between masters and replicas they still are better off skipping DDL part
altogether on replicas.
Thus, something which on a single-node master looks as straightforward as:
box.schema.space.create('myspace')
box.space.myspace:create_index('pk')
box.schema.user.grant('guest', 'read,write,execute', 'universe')
becomes something complicated when you make your startup script restart-aware and replication-aware.
What we could offer our users, is something like run-once hook, in which they can register
their functions. This hook would be guaranteed to execute only once in entire replica set,
and on the first start of the first master.
Something like:
box.run_once(create_spaces_and_users)
The implementation could use a special key in _schema space to check whether or not
the hook has already executed. 
We could even offer users some form of DDL versioning/schema upgrade with this approach, if we allow many hooks, each getting its own distinct/unique identifier:
So, to add new spaces, users could, in addition to an existing
box.run_once(create_spaces_and_users)
simply add
box.run_once(add_a_few_more_spaces_and_users)
and thus get an automatic "upgrade" of schema, which runs only once, guaranteed.

Yes, this is done on purpose, to support installations which don't need
authentication and access control. Guest is a special user. You should always
be able to connect as guest. In other words, you always have a
CONNECT privilege in tarantool. You can't do anything if you are
guest, though, unless you've been granted privileges.

http://tarantool.org - a NoSQL database in a Lua script
. Peter, in Tarantool, authentication is a standalone request, something like CHANGE-USER in MySQL. When you provide a password in URI, the client tries to issue AUTH request right after establishing a connection. In your case, it tries and it fails.  If you need to become guest, do not issue AUTH at all, it's the default user already. We can prohibit setting a password for guest user, so it will always fail.
I don't think it's a good idea to always return 'success' to AUTH request when user == guest, so in this place 'guest' is treaded like any other user.
