See the code:

Here's the replica sends ACKs to the master. Note, it only sends it if applier->writer_cond is signaled.
https://github.com/tarantool/tarantool/blob/352e1f7c7dda61d22d0c0c0b1fc34c5e5ea11c47/src/box/applier.cc#L131
The applier->writer_cond is signaled upon applying a row on the replica.
https://github.com/tarantool/tarantool/blob/352e1f7c7dda61d22d0c0c0b1fc34c5e5ea11c47/src/box/applier.cc#L556
Judging by the replica log, it looks like the applier was stalled due to long WAL write:
2019-03-11 16:18:24.095 [1565171] main/28584/applier/ W> too long WAL write: 1 rows at LSN 713876302: 3.188 sec
2019-03-11 16:18:28.443 [1565171] main/28584/applier/ W> too long WAL write: 1 rows at LSN 713878358: 2.154 sec
2019-03-11 16:18:28.443 [1565171] main/28584/applier/ W> too long WAL write: 1 rows at LSN 713878359: 2.151 sec
2019-03-11 16:18:28.681 [1565171] main/29085/applierw/ sio.cc:303 !> SystemError writev(2), called on fd 16, aka [::1]:49549: Connection reset by peer
2019-03-11 16:18:28.779 [1565171] main/28584/applier/ I> can't read row
2019-03-11 16:18:28.779 [1565171] main/28584/applier/ xrow.c:554 E> ER_MISSING_REQUEST_FIELD: Missing mandatory field 'tuple' in request
As a result, the master didn't receive an ACK in time and closed the connection:
https://github.com/tarantool/tarantool/blob/352e1f7c7dda61d22d0c0c0b1fc34c5e5ea11c47/src/box/relay.cc#L483

Why the connection wasn't reestablished though is a mystery to me. It looks like a bug somewhere in coio/sio causing the replica read and try to decode an incomplete row sent by the master right before closing the connection.
Thus there are two problems here to be fixed. The first one is the above-mentioned bug in sio. It will ameliorate the problem by making the error recoverable. The other problem is too long WAL writes causing the replication timeout. I don't think it's a replication issue: the problem is we write WALs to the system page cache without syncing them to disk; once there are too many dirty pages, the OS starts throttling writers until enough dirty pages have been flushed to disk. We've run into this problem before, e.g. see https://github.com/tarantool/tarantool/issues/3603#issuecomment-411815429. A workaround would be setting sysctl vm.dirty_bytes Linux option to a small value, say 10 MB. I think we should sync WALs explicitly, similarly to how we do it in case of SNAP files, see
https://github.com/tarantool/tarantool/blob/352e1f7c7dda61d22d0c0c0b1fc34c5e5ea11c47/src/box/xlog.c#L339
https://github.com/tarantool/tarantool/blob/352e1f7c7dda61d22d0c0c0b1fc34c5e5ea11c47/src/box/xlog.c#L1257. > The event loop stall may happen on a huge select as well, or when writing a huge tuple to WAL, then compression may take a while.
Stalling the event loop for several seconds by a CPU intensive workload smells like a bug in the application code, which is pretty easy to fix - just add fiber.yield() where appropriate. As for WAL compression - for it to stall the event loop for that long, we must insert hundreds megabytes per second, which is hardly possible.
Too long WAL writes caused by dirty page throttling is a completely different beast though - it may happen even if the application is designed perfectly well and the CPU is never overloaded. In fact, I have to set vm.dirty_bytes for write-intensive performance testing to avoid latency spikes. I think it's unfair to hand this problem over to users rather than fixing it in the server code, similarly to how we fixed #1359.. Looks like #3910. Please upgrade. mejedi:
Actually, \xc2 is missing, it happens because utf8('\x80') == '\xc2\x80'. Libyaml implements the following encoding logic:
1. If input is a malformed UTF-8 sequence, encode as !!binary.
2. Consume 1, 2, 3 or 4 bytes from the input string depending on the next UTF-8 character width. Convert to Unicode code point. If the code point is printable, emit bytes as is. Otherwise, emit \x??, \u???? or \U??????? escape sequence, depending on the code point's range.
3. Repeat until the whole input is consumed.
The fix: encode as !!binary if any code point above 0x7f needs to be escaped during step 2.

. Coeio is already reinited on fork.
Reinit proc just literally re-initializes eio library, discarding the previous state altogether. In case there were any async tasks posted they won't complete, ever (hung fibers).
We can extend eio with a function to wait until async task queue drains and we can call it before fork.
In order for this bug to manifest itself, one has to spawn additional fibers calling coeio before doing fork/box.cfg{background=true}/. Since we are having a race condition here the failures won't be deterministic.
Whether it's worth fixing is questionable. Personally I believe it SHOULD be impossible to write a code exploiting this issue, even if the code is convoluted and it is highly unlikely to be encountered in practice.
Note 1: calling box.cfg{} again complains about setting option 'background' dynamically, hence it is probably safe to assume fork happens only once. No test for setting 'background' option dynamically, there are tests for other similar options (custom_proc_title, etc).
Note 2: initialising database engine spawns threads. The engine fails to initialise unless box.cfg{} was already called, hence the issue doesn't apply to these threads.
Note 3: initialising db before calling box.cfg{} fails with somewhat wordy error (due to traceback). It would be more friendly to just say 'Please call box.cfg{} first'. Maybe it makes sense to call box.cfg{} implicitly in this case?

. It's sorta recursive. Txn thread may get busy preventing signal handlers in libev from running. Fine, move them to another thread. However the code triggered by the signal MUST run in the txn thread. We need some form of IPC with the txn thread. The busy event loop in the txn thread, which is the problem we were trying to sole in the first place, will render the IPC inoperable.
Sidenote: logrotate doesn't use libev and hence it doesn't suffer from the busy event loop.
. This was narrowed down to a bug in libcxxrt.
Go check __cxa_free_exception code.
c++
extern "C" void __cxa_free_exception(void *thrown_exception)
{
    __cxa_exception *ex = reinterpret_cast<__cxa_exception*>(thrown_exception) - 1;
    ...
}
__cxa_exception memory layout [def]:
__cxa_exception: { ...  { _Unwind_Exception: unwindHeader } }
i.e. unwind layer operates with _Unwind_Exception struct which is embeded inside __cxa_exception.
__cxa_free_exception gets a pointer to __Unwind_Exception but it does the math wrong while computing a pointer to the enclosing __cxa_exception.
We should file a bug for libcxxrt.

. ### Proposed API
lua
box.schema.func.reload('package.function') —> true, nil
                                           —> false, 'Error message'
Reload a shared library implementing the particular stored function. If the function is implemented in Lua, reports success and does nothing.
Other stored C functions from the same binary are implicitly reloaded as well.
Reload unloads the currently loaded instance of the shared library first. If reload fails, future calls to the affected stored C functions may fail as well.
Reload will fail if a library was loaded for other reasons rather than providing an implementation for a Tarantool C stored function. (Ex: also loaded in Lua script with ffi.load.)
lua
box.schema.func.reload('package')
Reload the entire package contents.
lua
box.schema.func.reload()
Reload everything.

. Current master builds on Ubuntu 12 / i386 with gcc4.6 just fine. And so does 1.6.
However, the core issue is us not setting the target architecture explicitly. The 'architecture' means the subset of the hardware features the compiled code relies upon (ex: i686(Pentium Pro) vs. core i7). Compiling for advanced architectures results in a binary that is generally running faster on recent hardware but it fails to run on older hw.
We depend on atomic instructions being present and it means -march=i686 or better. If the target architecture is an older one atomic instructions are n/a and the compiler inserts calls to emulation functions that are nowhere to be found, hence the linker error.
If -march= option is missing, the default architecture specified when gcc itself was built is used. To query the default do gcc -Q --help=target | grep -- -march. Some distributions have sensible defaults but some don't.
The suggestion is to specify target architecture explicitly. It must be decided what our min hardware requirements are. We shouldn't probably exceed the minimal hardware requirements of the distributions me are providing binary packages for.

. The following is the summary of an internal discussion.
Logger key (string) specifies the logging destination. In order to support different destinations in a uniform way the following syntax is adopted:
- "file:/path/to/file" — log to file;
- "pipe:/path/to/executable [param1 ...]" — log to a helper process via a pipe;
- "syslog:[key=value[,key=value...]]" — log to syslog.
The legacy logger syntax is retained for compatibility. The legacy syntax will be dropped in a future release.
Syslog Destination
The syntax is "syslog:" followed by an optional comma separated key=value list. The folowing keys are defined:
- identity=... — a string prepended to every syslog message (default: tarantool);
- facility=... — syslog facility (auth, authpriv, cron, daemon, ftp, kern, lpr, mail, news, security, syslog, user, uucp, local0 ... local7, default: user).
Note: the severy level of a message logged to syslog is set automatically.
Note: the proposed syntax is based on [1] and [2].
. # RFC: Cfg Module
1 Basic Usage
A config is a flat key-value dictionary. Valid keys must be registered.
If configuration data contains an unknown key the error is reported. If
a key is missing the default value is assumed (provided during
registration.)
Creating empty config object: 
lua
cfg = require('config').new()
Registering keys:
lua
cfg.reg('work_dir', '.', 'string') -- name, default value (optional),
                                   -- type(s) (optional)
Loading data:
lua
cfg.load_file('my.conf') -- or
cfg.load(lua_table) -- or
cfg.update(lua_table) -- load replaces data while
                      -- update merges new data with existing one
Both load and update validate the data. If validation fails existing
data is left intact.
Accessing the data:
lua
cfg.get('work_dir') -- or
cfg.data.work_dir
2 Nested Tables
A value is either of a primitive type (ex: a string, a number) or another
table. By default a nested table is treated as an opaque blob, i.e. if a
value was provided it is used as-is (not merging with defaults). However
if the nested table structure is known, the same rules apply as for
the root table (no unknown keys rule, merging with defaults):
lua
cfg.reg('sophia.memory_limit', 0, 'number')
3 Frozen Keys
This feature prevents changes to a certain key. If a load or update
changes a frozen key operation fails in the validation stage. 
lua
cfg.freeze('work_dir') -- prevent changes of the specific key
cfg.freeze('<set_once>') -- prevent changes of any tagged key,
                         -- tags are set during key registration,
                         -- ex: conf.reg('<tag>name', ...)
4 Listening for Changes
The following method enables to receive notifications when a certain key
changes due to a load or update operation:
lua
cfg.add_listener(function (cfg_data)
    print('Listen URI is now ' .. cfg_data.listen)
end)
A listener is invoked immediately upon registration. The function
is passed the configuration data. The list of keys accessed is built
transparently (internally cfg_data is a proxy object). 
Later if any key on the list changes the listener is invoked again
(building the updated keys list as a side effect). Listeners run after data validation in
update or load operation. 
Listeners MUST be prepared for spurious invocation, i.e. a config
implementation is technically permitted to invoke a listener even if no
relevant keys changed.
5 Preprocessing and Custom Validation
This feature enables preprocessing a value before it is assigned to a
key:
lua
cfg.reg('listen', nil, 'string, number', process_uri)
The function is invoked as follows:
lua
process_uri(new_value, old_value)
A function either accepts the new value or rejects it. If a function
retuns a value it is stored in the key (preprocessing). The
old_value is passed just in case a function decides to implement its own
strategy for merging changes.

. Internally, if work_dir is set, Tarantool does chdir() to that dir. This is when any symlinks are replaced with the target path, that's simply how chdir() works [1].
OP was doing code reload without restarting Tarantool. The following schema was implemented:
- code is deployed in a directory with a generated name;
- /var/lib/tarantool/scripts/service/data symlink was pointing to the current deploy dir;
- multiple versions can coexist; switching them is as easy as changing a single symlink.
In order for the code to properly load it was necessary to cd to the deploy dir (dependencies). However doing it through work_dir doesn't work because work_dir chdir()-s once and chdir() resolves symlinks.
Solution
Provide bindings for chdir(), to be called explicitly before reloading code. (#1141)
. ### Design Issues
Multiple fibers could get blocked waiting for the same object (fd). An object often provides an explicit close() method. Close invalidates the file descriptor; before closing it is necessary to unblock all fibers waiting for the descriptor and to prevent more fibers from getting blocked.
This logic is already implemented in highlevel wrapper in the socket module; we are going to need it in database connectors as well and probably all over the place.
Libev is easily hackable to enumerate and kill all watchers associated with a file descriptor.
The suggestion is to wrap a fd in a C structure (structure lifetime == object lifetime) and to change coio_wait() interface. This structure wrapper thing will allow for:
- associating flags with fd (to avoid ev_io_init overhead — see above);
- preventing fibers from blocking on an object that is about to die;
- allowing for coio_wait() generalizations: see next section.
coio_wait generalization
coio_wait() allows to wait for a fd + timeout. When it is necessary to wait for a larger set of events one has to write complex code involving libev watchers and fiber magic.
The suggestion is to implement coio_wait_N and polymorphic waitable objects (the suggested fd wrapper will be the first one).
This will provide a convenient coroutine-friendly interface and will allow to abstract from libev.

. Posting a little design spec to outline the direction we are going with net.box.
We are doing the major refactoring/rewriting with the following goals in mind:
- improve code structure making it more maintainable and approachable;
- the design must allow for an active net.box to be GC-ed, implicitly closing the connection;
- the performance is super important, it looks like the major source of overhead is fiber coordination; remove as much overhead as possible.
These goals are closely related, actually. To allow for GC, object graph must be carefully designed. If done carelessly, we will reproduce the situation we are currently facing — a background fiber referencing the connection prevents GC. Abstraction layers and similar features of a good design should be treated with extreme caution to avoid performance degradation.
1. Extracting net_connector
Tarantool speaks 2 network protocols:
1. console — a text protocol, human readable & writable (think telnet);
2. iproto — a binary protocol, DB queries + remote Lua code execution.
In both protocols a server speaks first. The initial server message mentions the protocol being used. The initial server message is compatible between protocols, allowing for a protocol-oblivious client. For instance, a remote console can work on top of both protocols.
However, iproto is a much more feature-rich protocol. Currently, console is implemented on top of the net.box. The later speaks both protocols, but unless the wire protocol is iproto, net.box is in the special degraded mode with all requests but EVAL failing.
We are extracting the basic connection facility into net_connector object. The later is responsible for establishing the connection, multiplexing simultaneous requests and parsing responses. The client API is relatively low level — a client obtains a send buffer with begin_response(). She renders the request in the buffer provided. Finally, the client invokes wait_response() obtaining a response.
lua
m = net_connector('<url>', { <options> } )
status, buf, id = m.begin_request(timeout);
if (status) then
  format_request(buf, id, 'SELECT', ...)
  return m.wait_response(id, timeout)
end
The connector performs implicit close on GC. In the absence of user references it is collected, eventually.
Both remote console and net.box build on top of net_connector.
2. The Internals of a net_connector
The connector employs a single background fiber. The later executes the following procedure:
1. connect;
2. read handshake;
3. invoke a protocol-specific procedure.
The iproto procedure goes as follows:
1. do auth;
2. repeatedly extract a response, and dispatch it to the matching fiber;
3. (while waiting for a response, send buffered outgoing data;)
4. (if a response code indicates an outdated schema, run update-schema procedure.)
The programming model is as follows:
- There is a socket, plus a send buffer plus a receive buffer.
- The background fiber is responsible for moving data between the socket and buffers.
- The task is accomplished with send_and_recv() primitive. It flushes send_buf and puts incoming data in recv_buffer until either N bytes are available or a boundary string is encountered. Send and receive activities are happening concurrently.
- Protocol-specific routines recv_console_response() and recv_iproto_response() are built on top of the send_and_recv() primitive.
- The background fiber has direct access to both buffers.
- User obtains send_buf form begin_request() method. It is mandatory to begin a request with begin_request(). The method waits if requests aren't allowed in the current state or if send_buffer usage exceeds a limit. The method also ensures that an ongoing send_and_recv() will notice the newly queued data (we assume yield doesn't happen until the request is rendered).
Wait_response() inserts the calling fiber into an internal table keyed by id. The fiber then sleeps until woken by a protocol-specific procedure.
3. C Aid
For the reasons of simplicity and efficiency, several parts are implemented in C.
3.1 Fiber.event
A light-weight sibling of the fiber.channel, this object is not unlike POSIX condition variable.
- wait() — puts the current fiber to sleep, until explicitly woken;
- signal() — wake all waiting fibers (FIFO order).
The intended pattern is to wait() in a loop while a condition is false.
3.2 Iomux
IO multiplexer implements the core of begin_request() and send_and_recv() primitives. Precisely,
- imx_sender_checkin() —
  - waits for the proper state;
  - waits until send_buf usage is below a threshold;
  - notifies an ongoing send_and_receive.
- imx_line_service() — send_and_receive.
A few IO multiplexer fields are exposed to Lua via FFI, allowing for efficient buffer access. The multiplexer setups socket IO using libev watchers in the most efficient manner possible (not a single syscall wasted!)
Often, a sender will bypass the overhead of imx_sender_checkin() Lua-C call (fast field, see sources). Last but not least, wakeups in IO multiplexer are efficient (think thundering herd).
lua
ffi.cdef([[
    struct tarantool_iomux
    {
        ptrdiff_t   fast;
        struct ibuf send;
        struct ibuf recv;
        char        _[?];
    };
]]);
. Preliminary results arrived: 15%  to 20% performance improvement!
1M pings in 10K concurrent fibers (-20%):
This one measures the overhead of fibers coordination and exchanging requests and responses. The messages themselves are very small.
$ time ./tarantool benchmark_new_net.lua
real    0m2.288s
user    0m2.127s
sys     0m0.065s
$ time ./tarantool benchmark_old_net.lua
real    0m2.899s
user    0m2.793s
sys     0m0.092s
100K selects in 1K concurrent fibers (-15%):
Performing the real requests here! Each result is ~700 bytes, expanding into ~250 objects on 3 nesting levels.
```
$ time ./tarantool benchmark_new_net.lua
real    0m1.877s
user    0m1.749s
sys     0m0.056s
```
$ time ./tarantool benchmark_old_net.lua
real    0m2.193s
user    0m2.109s
sys     0m0.084s
What Did the Profiler Say?
PING results were hardly surprising. However in SELECT test we were expecting to see little to no difference since the major time is spent performing msgpack serialisation. Check out the flame graphs:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/h6bz1tw8avm73lu/new_box.svg?dl=0
https://www.dropbox.com/s/zsqlolc771xeuxv/old_box.svg?dl=0
It appears that msgpack serialisation indeed takes up to 80% time.
However there is on important difference: lj_tab_newkey stack that is responsible for more than 8% running time in the current implementation is virtually missing from the new implementation's flame graph!
It appears that SELECT has a significantly higher latency than PING, hence more fibers are waiting for a response simultaneously. In the current implementation there are ~10 insert operations involving a hash table sized proportional to the number of waiting fibers, per requests (lj_tab_newkey).
The new implementation performs only 2 inserts per request.
To validate our hypothesis we've tested the current implementation again reducing concurrency to 100 fibers, lj_tab_newkey disappeared completely, supporting our conclusions.
rehashtab
You may wonder, why does the size of a hash table matter if insert complexity is O(1). The reason is LuaJIT growing/shrinking the hash table dynamically as the size changes. The flame graph shows that the majority of lj_tab_newkey running time is spent in the nested call to rehashtab.

. Re-opening for discussion.
The burning question is how to introduce new features in connectors while maintaining backwards compatibility. We should decide how to implement it in net.box and use it as a model for other connectors.
Basically we have three options:
1. Leave call method as is, add call_17 to request new marshalling for early adopters.
2. Modify call to behave in 1.7 semantics, add call_16 for back compat.
3. Smart call behaving as call_16/call_17 depending on the server version + call_16 and call_17.
Option 1 is conservative and doesn't break things.
Option 2 may work but requires complex migration procedure which needs to be documented:
- Tarantool team neads to implement call_16 in 1.6 branch;
- the latest 1.6 Tarantool is deployed;
- application is updated to use call_16 in place of call;
- finally update Tarantool to 1.7.
Option 3 doesn't work because of the scalars (net.box user has to write different code depending on the server version, even more broken code.)
Personally, I like option 1 most. We could do option 2 but we should update connectors first for consistency and that's hard to do in a timely fashion because of the connectors maintained by the community.
. Summing up discussion with @kostja:
- Call semantics (1.6 vs 1.7) is defined in connect options and is independent of the actual server version.
- Default is 1.7.
- Connectors must implement similar option, starting with Python. Consistency matters!
- Migration procedure will be included in the docs.
Once the interested parties agree on this, I am updating the linked tickets and creating one in docs.

. Confirmed that this issue was yet another manifestation of #1638.
. It's a quirk of the current fiber scheduler; not a bug.
Basically, when the parent fiber spawns a child via fiber.create, the new fiber starts executing immediately. Once the child reaches fiber.sleep(), it yields allowing for the parent to resume. At this point, the next line following fiber.create() executes and f.storage.xxx is set.
BTW, the behaviour is described in the docs: https://tarantool.org/doc/reference_lua/fiber.html#lua-function.fiber.create

I'd like to elaborate. I like @rtsisyk proposal for adding extendable options a lot. 
The downside of :opts and :timeout interface is implementation complexity and runtime overhead. The complexity is due to the fact that :opts and :timeout must be aware of each other. This interface resemble currying concept — i.e. given a function, create a new one taking fewer arguments. The new function invokes the original one, passing constants for missing arguments. Ex: add_1 = curry(add, 1).
It's technically legal to have invocation like :opt({A=1}):opts({B=2}):opts({C=3}), with every subsequent opts creating a new context based on existing one.
Runtime overhead is due to the need to create a new object for each :opts and :timeout call.

A side note. The current :timeout implementation is a mess. Timeout uses the global table keyed by the calling fiber. It would be reasonable to expect that :timeout sets a default timeout for any connection method. Once we did c_t_1 = conn:timeout(1), the expectation is that c_t_1:methodA() will fail if it takes longer than 1 second to complete. No matter how methodA fared, the subsequent c_t_1:methodB() should still have 1 second timeout applied.
Actually, the timeout is 1 second minus methodA execution time! If methodA timed out, the timeout is cleared and methodB will never timeout even if it hangs forever!
Since the global table is keyed by the calling fiber, passing c_t_1 to another fiber will clear the timeout.
End side note.

If we were re-designing the API from scratch, I would suggest making every API call use named parameters (there's no such thing in Lua, hence a table.) That way, extending the API with new optional parameters in a consistent way would be easy.
The less radical approach would be retrofitting options table into existing API in a consistent fashion.
Since call and eval take variable number of arguments, I suggest adding new functions with the following signature:
func( options, name_or_code, param1, ... )
I.e. options go first!
There's another issue @rtsisyk didn't mention. Currently, :select() argument is optional. Adding options create an ambiguity: how to treat :select() with 1 argument?. Dup of #2202 .

@bigbes Done in https://github.com/tarantool/tarantool-zmq ?
(Also filed https://github.com/tarantool/rocks/issues/52 ). We can create a tuple from already encoded data like so:
```
!/usr/bin/env tarantool
local ffi = require('ffi')
local buffer = require('buffer')
local msgpackffi = require('msgpackffi')
local yaml = require('yaml')
ffi.cdef([[
    struct box_tuple_format_t;
    struct box_tuple_t;
box_tuple_format_t *
box_tuple_format_default(void);

box_tuple_t *
box_tuple_new(box_tuple_format_t *format, const char *data,
              const char *end);

int
box_tuple_ref(box_tuple_t *tuple);

struct ibuf;

]])
-- prepare data
local source_data = {1, 2, 3}
local buf = buffer.ibuf()
msgpackffi.internal.encode_r(buf, source_data, 0)
local data_start = buf.buf
local data_end = buf.buf + buf:size()
-- create tuple
local def_format = ffi.C.box_tuple_format_default()
local tuple = ffi.C.box_tuple_new(def_format, data_start, data_end)
ffi.C.box_tuple_ref(tuple)
tuple = ffi.cast('const box_tuple_t &', tuple)
print(type(tuple))
print(tostring(tuple))
print(yaml.encode(tuple))
```. Note: referenced openssl issues were updated with 'all done' comments recently.. The issue seems to be fixed.

function utils.fromhex(str_hex)
    local err_msg = 'bad hex string'
    local matches = {string.match(str_hex, '^([0-9A-Fa-f]+)$')}
    if #matches ~= 1 then return false, err_msg end
    if str_hex:len() % 2 ~= 0 then return false, err_msg end
    local res_lst = {}
    for i = 1, str_hex:len() / 2 do
        local byte_str = string.sub(str_hex, 2 * i - 1, 2 * i)
        res_lst[i] = string.char(tonumber(byte_str, 16))
    end
    return true, table.concat(res_lst)
end. Note: string.hex implementation: 0ca6cb87dfd69b3f39024c714c8fde9b2dd9acbf.. Notes for implementation:

Title: socket:recv() / socket:recvfrom() updates
- API change (for a UDP socket after #3619): a datagram will not be truncated to 512 bytes and the input buffer size will be evaluated when no explicit size was passed (but the evaluating leads to extra syscall); check the commit message for more information.
- API undocumented (for a UDP socket): a datagram will be truncated to size length in case when explicit size was passed, but the datagram length is larger then the size; the tail of the datagram will be discarded in the case; don't forget to note TCP behaviour (it is very different); check the commit message for more information.
- Recommendation missed: recommended to set size explicitly for recv and recvfrom; don't forget to give recommendations whether it is possible to determine the size (message format, network conditions) and how to do so depending of network conditions (add note that datagram sizes above MTU will lead to IP fragmentation that can be inefficient; add note that there is tuneable sysctl net.inet.udp.maxdgram on Mac OS); check the commit message for more information.
- Minor: update 'Use of a UDP socket on localhost' to use explicit size (say, 512), because we will recommend it for readers.
- Minor: ToC sorting is such that recv is far away from recvfrom.
- Monor: inconsistency in parameters naming: recv(size) vs recvfrom(limit). The size term should be preferred IMHO, because AFAIK the word 'size' usually applied for the size of a buffer (while 'length' usually applied to a message length).

```diff
git diff
diff --git a/src/box/xlog.c b/src/box/xlog.c
index f258e4c..ae0dcef 100644
--- a/src/box/xlog.c
+++ b/src/box/xlog.c
@@ -895,7 +895,8 @@ xdir_create_xlog(struct xdir dir, struct xlog xlog,
        if (xlog_create(xlog, filename, dir->open_wflags, &meta) != 0)
                return -1;

/ set sync interval from xdir settings /
/ set sync interval and is_async from xdir settings /
xlog->sync_is_async = dir->sync_is_async;
        xlog->sync_interval = dir->sync_interval;
        / free file cache if dir should be synced /
        xlog->free_cache = dir->sync_interval != 0 ? true: false;
```

All other results are got with vm.dirty_ratio = 20 (20% of RAM is ~18.8GiB).

```
diff --git a/cmake/FindICONV.cmake b/cmake/FindICONV.cmake

-if (TARGET_OS_LINUX)
+if (TARGET_OS_LINUX OR TARGET_OS_FREEBSD)
     set(ICONV_LIBRARY "")
 else()
     find_library(ICONV_LIBRARY iconv)
@@ -13,9 +13,11 @@ else()
         set(ICONV_LIBRARY "")
     endif()
 endif()
-find_path(ICONV_INCLUDE_DIR iconv.h)
-if(NOT ICONV_INCLUDE_DIR)

+    find_path(ICONV_INCLUDE_DIR iconv.h)

+        message(FATAL_ERROR "iconv include header not found")

 set(ICONV_INCLUDE_DIRS ${ICONV_INCLUDE_DIR})

So, as you can see, the standard says: that there are 3 types of identifiers:
1) regular identifier (eg table1, таблица1)
2) delimited identifier (eg "table1", "table 1", "таблица 1", "1table", "table""1" -> table"1)
3) Unicode delimited identifier (eg U&"\FF83\FF70\FF8C \FF9E\FF99") not supported by sqlite
Sqlite identifiers:
1) as in standard
2) as in sdandard + two delimiters : ' , [ ] which allow eg 'table''1' -> table'1
3) not supported
Tarantool identifiers:
1) as in standard
2) as in sdandard + two delimiters : ' , [ ] , but only letters(not only ascii), digits, underscore allowed inside
3) not supported
What are suggestions?. in sqlite parse.c the following constructions are declared as identifiers:
1. pragma smth=identifier
2. RAISE(ABORT, identifier);
but accordint to standard, identifiers should be delimited by ", which makes us use eg
1. pragma characterset="utf-8"
2. RAISE(ABORT, "some error");
But I think that in those cases we are dealing not with identifiers, but with strings, and correct syntax is:
1. pragma characterset='utf-8'
2. RAISE(ABORT, 'some error');
If nobody answers me soon, I go to the ANSI ISO again
Update
I have not found any information on it in ANSI ISO 2003, so I suppose this statements should not be treated as identifiers. I have made some refactoring on Kirills comment:
Identifier validation as in tarantool:
Identifiers in tarantool allow only [a-Z0-9_], SQL identifiers should follow the same rules so that identifiers can be easily used from Lua.
Here are some points that should be considered:
- [x] table names as in tarantool
- [x] index names as in tarantool
- [ ] ? column names as in tarantool (it do not work in tarantool itself #2914) I suppose this point could be solved automatically after SQL starts using formats.
- [ ] ? virtual tables. Should its names have the same constraints? Cause it is not accessible from tarantool.
- [ ] ? collation names, aliases, and other identifiers. Should they also follow these rules?
Chousen solution

Validate every identifier with the same function in Tarantool and in SQL
Use sql standard rules for validation (see #2123  for more info)

Extra issues:

[x] All delimited identifiers are specified using symbol (")
[x] All string literals are specified using symbol (')
[x] Any other quotation is prohibited
[x] +- true Rules for all identifiers are the same. (not implemented at least for collations and col names)
[x] All keywords mentioned in Chapter 5.2 (" and ") cannot
be used as identifiers, both delimited and regular
[ ] Maximal length of identifier is limited to 64KB (what for? check needed)
[ ] Support UESCAPE, with lower priority though

[ ] We will allow using UTF-8 identifiers: only delimited (I see only
in the standard). Comparison of
such identifiers will be done using libICU facilities

Here is some info on this issue from 2003 standard:
Syntax
```
 ::= ||
 ::= COLLATE 
 ::=| 
 ::=   
 ::=
   | | | 
   | | | | 
   | | | | 
   | | | | 
   | | | 
 ::=| 
 ::=| 
 ::=   
 ::=  [  ]
 ::=| 
 ::=  | 
 ::=  |  
    | | | | 
    | | | 
 ::= { UPPER | LOWER }   
```
General Rules
If <fold> is specified, then:

Let S be the value of the .
If S is the null value, then the result of the  is the null value.
Let FRML be the length or maximum length in characters of the declared type of .
Case:
If UPPER is specified, then let FR be a copy of S in which every lower case character that has
a corresponding upper case character or characters in the character set of S and every title case
character that has a corresponding upper case character or characters in the character set of S is
replaced by that upper case character or characters.
If LOWER is specified, then let FR be a copy of S in which every upper case character that has
a corresponding lower case character or characters in the character set of S and every title case
character that has a corresponding lower case character or characters in the character set of S is
replaced by that lower case character or characters.


If the character set of  is UTF8, UTF16, or UTF32, then FR is replaced by
Case:
If the  S IS NORMALIZED evaluated to True, then NORMALIZE (FR)
Otherwise, FR.


Let FRL be the length in characters of FR.
Case:
If FRL is less than or equal to FRML, then the result of the  is FR. If the declared type of
FR is fixed-length character string, then the result is padded on the right with (FRML – FRL)
s.
If FRL is greater than FRML, then the result of the  is the first FRML characters of FR
with length FRML. If any of the right-most (FRL – FRML) characters of FR are not 
characters, then a completion condition is raised: warning — string data, right truncation.



It can be inferred from here that the only way to pass locale to UPPER/LOWER functions is to get it from expression.
It has 2 problems:
1. It is hard to implement
2. It require additional colculations in case of JIT, because collation can not be inferred at compile time (due to functions. case when clauses...)
. #### Two approaches to implement upper/lower:

UPPER( string, locale_name) (e.g. UPPER('hello', 'ru_RU'))
UPPER(string, collation_name_in_tarantool) (e.g. UPPER('hello', "unicode_ci"))

First solution
Disadvantages:
- The locale name is not checked by icu. In case of invalid locale - the default locale is chosen silently.
Second solution
Disadvantages:
- We can not get UCaseMap object from our struct coll, so to create UCaseMap we need to:
  - query tuple from _collation space by name
  - create UCaseMap based on fetched locale
- Create collation is not a public API, so it would require some patience to do UPPER with locale which is not in our _collation space
- The locale name is not checked by icu when creating collation too
Which locale to use if it is not set
There is a case: UPPER("hello")
Which locale to use?:
- binary (default in sqlite, do upper only for ASCII) (Kirill for it)
- unicode (default icu) (Kostya for it)

For simple queries (dml), concurrent executions work pretty fine.. The thing is that box api (box.cc) which is currently in use by sqlite engine takes msgpack as an argument.
If Op_MakeRecord produces tuple, the box.cc takes only msgpack part of this tuple and will create a new tuple and copy all data to it. At this point, we have already copied the data at least three times (to sqlite registers, to create msgpack and to create tuple).
At the same time, tuples we can create by now (of default type) do not give us any advantages over msgpacks, because it does not store offsets to the fields.
All these points convinced us to create an intermediate layer for direct tuple insertions in box api.. ## We discussed this topic once again.
There were two reasons to replace msgpack with tuples:
1. to retrieve fields in O(1) time, because tuples are indexed (now O(n))
2. to copy data as less as possible
About the reason 1.:
We decided to store in Mem struct retrieved by select from tarantool not only msgpack but optional tuple too. When we need to retrieve a column from this Mem we try to use tuple first.
About the reason 2.:
It is a little bit bad to insert tuples to memtx, because memtx know which tuple format it needs to store and creates it from msgpack as it should be.
In case of vinyl, the copying cannot be eliminated because it has more complex tuple format.
Results:

to not replace msgpacks with tuples
to add optional tuple to the data structure which is the result of select from tarantool engine to improve indexing (Op_Column) speed

```lua
local utf8 = require('utf8')
local function eq(left, right)
    return left == right
end
local function lt(left, right)
    return left < right
end
local function bool_lt(left, right)
    return (not left) and right
end
local function unicode_lt(left, right)
    return utf8.cmp(left, right) < 0
end
local function unicode_eq(left, right)
    return utf8.cmp(left, right) == 0
end
local function unicode_ci_lt(left, right)
    return utf8.casecmp(left, right) < 0
end
local function unicode_ci_eq(left, right)
    return utf8.casecmp(left, right) == 0
end
local function sort_tuples(index, primary_index, tuples, reverse)
    for , cmpindex in ipairs({index, primary_index}) do
        for , part in ipairs(cmpindex.parts) do
            if part.type == 'boolean' then
                part.lt = bool_lt
                part.eq = eq
            elseif part.type == 'string' then
                if part.collation == 'unicode' then
                    part.lt = unicode_lt
                    part.eq = unicode_eq
                elseif part.collation == 'unicode_ci' then
                    part.lt = unicode_ci_lt
                    part.eq = unicode_ci_eq
                else
                    part.lt = lt
                    part.eq = eq
                end
            else
                part.lt = lt
                part.eq = eq
            end
        end
    end
local lessthan =
    function (left, right)
        for _, cmpindex in ipairs({index, primary_index})  do
            for _, part in ipairs(cmpindex.parts) do

                if part.lt(left[part.fieldno], right[part.fieldno]) then
                    return true
                elseif not part.eq(left[part.fieldno], right[part.fieldno]) then
                    return false
                end
            end
        end
        return false
    end

if reverse == true then
    local original_lessthan = lessthan
    lessthan = function(left, right) return not original_lessthan(left, right) end
end

table.sort(tuples, lessthan)

end

crudbug:
I was thinking about this same thing. OrientDB provides multi-model data persistence with Document, Object and Graph models. The idea is to treat vertices and edges as documents making relationships as first class citizens with no joining cost at runtime, traversals are O(1) . Lua 5.3
Main changes

Lua standalone interpreter

arg table available to all code

Lua 5.2
Main changes

yieldable pcall and metamethods
new lexical scheme for globals
ephemeron tables
new library for bitwise operations
light C functions
emergency garbage collector
goto statement
finalizers for tables

Language

no more fenv for threads or functions
tables honor the __len metamethod
hex and \z escapes in strings
support for hexadecimal floats
order metamethods work for different types
no more verification of opcode consistency
hook event "tail return" replaced by "tail call"
empty statement
break statement may appear in the middle of a block

Libraries

arguments for function called through xpcall
optional 'mode' argument to load and loadfile (to control binary x text)

new function package.searchpath
modules receive their paths when loaded
optional base in math.log
optional separator in string.rep
file:write returns file

new option 'isrunning' for collectgarbage and lua_gc
frontier patterns
\0 in patterns
new option *L for io.read
options for io.lines
debug.getlocal can access function varargs

C API

main thread predefined in the registry
new functions lua_absindex, lua_arith, lua_compare, lua_copy, lua_len, lua_rawgetp, lua_rawsetp, lua_upvalueid, lua_upvaluejoin, lua_version.
new functions luaL_checkversion, luaL_setmetatable, luaL_testudata, luaL_tolstring.
lua_pushstring and pushlstring return string
nparams and isvararg available in debug API
new lua_Unsigned

Implementation

max constants per function raised to 226
generational mode for garbage collection (experimental)
NaN trick (experimental)
internal (immutable) version of ctypes
simpler implementation for string buffers
parser uses much less C-stack space (no more auto arrays)
Lua standalone interpreter
new -E option to avoid environment variables
handling of non-string error messages
. > I mean, why this stored sync could not be implicitly used?

Because the value of sync changes per request, and another request may be handled before box.session.push is called.
What if the fiber was "weakly mapped" to sync? Then box.session.push could map fiber.self to the proper sync.
```lua
-- Stored wherever the Lua functions are called from.
local sync_map = {}
sync_map.__mode = "k"
-- Do this for each request.
sync_map[request_fiber] = sync
-- Inside box.session.push
local sync = sync_map[fiber.self()]
```. > it is the same, as storing sync inside a fiber
Not identical, because the weak map avoids storing application-specific data on the abstract fiber.

It is additional overhead to maintain this map (fiber count can be huge)

Forgive my ignorance, but is the overhead really bad? There's overhead with storing sync in a local variable, right? What's the reason a weak map is less efficient?

And don't forget about C api, Swift, Rust, etc.

Their require system works very similarly to NodeJS:

Relative paths are supported (eg: ./init for sibling modules or ../init to traverse up directories)
Module names still work (eg: foo/bar or foo.bar)

There's probably more to it than that, but luvit's documentation is sparse on the subject. Anyway, the relative require calls are reason enough to have something like this, in my opinion.
Someone made a npm-like package manager for luvit, called lum. Its benefits are listed here. Although it's not mature, perhaps there are some things to learn from its design that can be applied to Tarantool's package manager. Easy dependency declaration via package.lua and installation of project dependencies into the ./modules directory. And it might be compatible with luarocks packages.
[5]: https://groups.google.com/d/msg/luvit/MPGM3rKzDrw/5TQw9jC6628J. This implementation works good in Tarantool: https://github.com/aleclarson/lula/blob/master/loader.lua
It's more comfortable for people coming from a NodeJS background.
```lua
-- Load 'foo.lua' or 'foo/init.lua' sibling
require "./foo"
-- Load 'foo.lua' or 'foo/init.lua' in parent directory
require "../foo"
-- Traverse multiple parents
require "../../foo/bar"
```
To keep the implementation lightweight, only modules within the working directory can use relative paths. The working directory is determined using os.getenv('PWD'), but that may be broken for some platforms (tested on OS X).

. Run meta tuple will have a flag if prefix compression is enabled.
All run keys are ordered, so if we have multipart key then we can have
same keys prefixes for adjacent tuples for example:
x1 y1 z1 v1
x1 y1 z2 v2
x1 y1 z3 v3
x1 y2 z4 v4
x2 y2 z5 v5
x2 y3 z6 v6
x2 y3 z7 v7
x2 y3 z8 v8
who x, y, z - keys, v - values.
This sequence can be encoded as:
0 x1 y1 z1 v1
2 z2 v2
2 z3 v3
1 y2 z4 v4
0 x2 y2 z5 v5
1 y3 z6 v6
2 z7 v7
2 z8 v8
who first item is the count of equal fields with previous tuple.
If there is no equal prefixes for adjacent tuples we will lose one byte for zero
value (mp_stream encoded)
If we have equal key prefix with size l then we will won (l - 1) byte (zero, for
unsigned keys less than 128, or more in any other cases).
Compression should be done before xrow will be sent to xlog. We can store last
written tuple and compare next tuple against it to decide count of matching
fields.
Decompression may be done while vinyl page restoration, we can store last
restored tuple to get appropriate values.

danikin:
A good document. I like it! Also we need to take into account the following things:

Specifying an algorithm for data distribution across shards
Specifying a field/key which is used as a parameter for the algorithm above
Specifying presence/absence of distributed transactions
Specifying a list of nodes that act as coordinators for distributed transactions
Also I'm not sure that we need to make specific shard numbers for a specific machine (like shard X). In my view, we just need to give machines zones and then the system decides automatically how to shard or how to replicate. This gives a user more flexibility as they just add or remove a machine to/from a specific zone and then the system decides either it needs to use it for retaining redundancy to to shard data. In that scenario we need to let a user configure it - which thing is more prioritized - to retain redundancy or to shard data within known limitations of having zones. Also we should have sub-zones. Say, if I can't restore redundancy to my target redundancy factor within zones (datacenters) then I might want to do that within a sub-zone ( separate buildings within a datacenter) or sub-sub-zone (separate halls within a building with a dedicated power outlet) or a sub-sub-sub zone (separate racks within a hall) or even a sub-sub-sub-sub zone (separate machine within a rack).
Specifying priority of a local configuration vs a cluster configuration. Sometimes I just want to get a machine out of a cluster and make it a separate machine. In this case I need to make sure that a cluster configuration does not substitute all the data on the machine with something else needed for the cluster to be working right now, even if I return a machine back to the cluster by accident.

. I came up with an idea how to deal with this problem.
According to this piece of code if there is nothing to read then read_reply returns immediately:
static int
tnt_net_reply(struct tnt_stream *s, struct tnt_reply *r) {
    if (s->wrcnt == 0)
        return 1;
    pm_atomic_fetch_sub(&s->wrcnt, 1);
    return tnt_reply_from(r, (tnt_reply_t)tnt_net_recv_cb, s);
}
So what I need to do is just to check read_reply on 1 return value. If it is 1 then there is nothing to read and I should just wait.
But I'm still a little bit concerned about this feature. Is it documented?

FZambia:
Hi, just to put my two cents into this discussion.
First of all here is a link to a great list of existing real-time technologies
Modern real-time frameworks can't rely on Websocket only. Most (Meteor and others) players on this stage use polyfills to fallback to HTTP-based transports (persistent like Eventsource, xhr-streaming or polling like xhr-polling, jsonp-polling). The reason is not only browser support but bugs in browser implementations (mostly fixed to this moment), mobile browsers (some still not supporting Websockets), proxies (as real-time application goes to the wild some proxies do not pass websocket traffic - this mostly can be solved using wss:// instead of ws://), see https://speakerdeck.com/3rdeden/websuckets presentation to get more information.
Polyfills also has some drawbacks to mention. For example SockJS HTTP transports require using sticky sessions when connecting to application backend (so client reconnected to the same node after receiving message in case of long-polling). HTTP transports limit you to using text communication protocol (binary support is a great win in case of dynamic multiplayer real-time games - see for example agar.io). And it's also more to develop both on client and server side.

When you run the default values, \n is used as the line separator; however, if you change it to a different # character, the new separator becomes #\n. And the line that came from telnet contains bytes#\r\n, which does not correspond to #\n.. This functionality seems to be already in Tarantool:

diff --git a/src/box/lua/console.lua b/src/box/lua/console.lua

@@ -67,6 +67,7 @@ local function set_language(storage, value)

     end

     storage.language = value

 end
@@ -316,7 +317,11 @@ local function local_read(self)
                 break
             end
         elseif #buf >= #delim and buf:sub(#buf - #delim + 1) == delim then
-            buf = buf:sub(0, #buf - #delim)
+            local sub_len = #buf - #delim
+            if box.session.language == 'sql' and delim == ';' then
+                sub_len = sub_len + 1
+            end
+            buf = buf:sub(0, sub_len)
             break
         end
         buf = buf.."\n"
@@ -354,8 +359,12 @@ local function client_read(self)
         -- Escape sequence to close current connection (like SSH)
         return nil
     end
-    -- remove trailing delimiter
-    return buf:sub(1, -#delim-1)
+    -- remove trailing delimiter if it is not SQL ;
+    if box.session.language == 'sql' and delim == ';' then

+    else
+        return buf:sub(1, -#delim-1)
+    end
 end

@kostja . The only place where pCursor->hint is set NOW is OP_ReopenIdx, OP_OpenRead, OP_OpenWrite
--> (pOp->p5 & (OPFLAG_BULKCSR|OPFLAG_SEEKEQ)) mask based on VDBE P5 VALUE:
1. OPFLAG_BULKCSR  == BTREE_BULKLOAD
2. OPFLAG_SEEKEQ    == BTREE_SEEK_EQ

The BTREE_BULKLOAD hint was used in src/box/sql/btree.c in balance function
balance_nonroot(MemPage * pParent,  / Parent page of siblings being balanced /
        int iParentIdx, / Index of "the page" in pParent /
        u8 * aOvflSpace,    / page-size bytes of space for parent ovfl /
        int isRoot, / True if pParent is a root-page /
        int bBulk   / True if this call is part of a bulk load /
    )
to fill last flag bBulk.

With @Korablev77 patch 7a56118b2f530b6ec994dd88b2042969c95d337d 
sql: remove original SQLite backend 
this btree.c become useless and was dropped.
So, BTREE_BULKLOAD, same as OPFLAG_BULKCSR could be deleted.

a) First of all, part of code is wrapped in SQLITE_ENABLE_CURSOR_HINTS that is disabled in tarantool build. I've dropped all the code in such sections and going to review the remaining one.

b) The flag is used in sqlite3CursorMovetoUnpacked (OP_SeekLE and OP_SeekGE) to setup iter_type, in (OP_SeekLT, OP_SeekLE, OP_SeekGE, OP_SeekGT), (OP_NoConflict, OP_NotFound, OP_Found), (OP_IdxDelete)
c) The VDBE P5 argument is setted OPFLAG_SEEKEQ by (1)sql_create_index, (2)sqlite3WhereBegin.
c.1:  sql_create_index
sqlite3VdbeAddOp4Int(v, OP_OpenWrite, iCursor,  index_space_ptr_reg, 6);
sqlite3VdbeChangeP5(v, OPFLAG_SEEKEQ);
This means that new cursor would have BTREE_SEEK_EQ==OPFLAG_SEEKEQ and then on lookup with OP_SeekLE (in getNewIid) that allows choose correct behavior on find and iter_type.
In other words, this match flag description
* If the cursor P1 was opened using the OPFLAG_SEEKEQ flag, then this
 * opcode will always land on a record that equally equals the key, or
 * else jump immediately to P2.  When the cursor is OPFLAG_SEEKEQ, this
 * opcode must be followed by an IdxLE opcode with the same arguments.
 * The IdxLE opcode will be skipped if this opcode succeeds, but the
 * IdxLE opcode will be used on subsequent loop iterations.
and this scenario is still in use. We should keep it.

. Tarantool has been crashing when trying to go into an
interactive loop in ncurses-libs/libtinfo library via
lbox_console_readline.
Ncurses on Fedora 28 is compiled with flag
--fstack-clash-protection that use stack protection
mechanism (strictly speaking configure option --enable-widec
is also required, but it is not a part of problem we
investigated): gcc inserting code to step the stack down
one page at a time, running a logical-OR with zero
at each point, which doesn't affect any value on the stack
but forces a memory access:
     lea r11,[rsp-frameSize]
 label:
     sub rsp,pageSize
     or QWORD PTR [rsp],0x0
     cmp rsp,r11
     jne label
```
where frameSize=32768 b and pageSize=4096 b
(read also https://ldpreload.com/blog/stack-smashes-you)
Tarantool main interactive loop is working in fiber with
default stack size 65536 b
```
BINARY IMAGE MEMORY MAP:

SECTION      ADDRESSES       COMMENT
DATA         0x0       ^
HEAP                   |
             0x0ec18   |  # < --fstack-clash-
                       |  #   protection check
STACK: @               |  #
       @     0x16c18   | $# < ncurses/readline
       @               | $    internals, access
       @               | $    syscall in wrapper
       @               | $
       @               | $
       @     0x1ffe0   | $  < frame0 -- LUA
             ....      |
             0xffff    |
+------+-----------------------------+-------------+
| SIGN | DESCRIPTION                 | TOTAL SIZE  |
+------+-----------------------------+-------------+
|  @   | stack area region; (fiber)  |   65536 b   |
+------+-----------------------------+-------------+
|  $   | user-space application stack|   37832 b   |
|      | memory usage                |             |
+------+-----------------------------+-------------+
|  #   | a memory that checked stack |   32768 b   |
|      | probing generated with      |             |
|      | --fstack-clash-protection   |             |
+------+-----------------------------+-------------+

In other words, $ + # = 70600    >    65536 = @
and we have segfault:
SIGSEGV {si_signo=SIGSEGV, si_code=SEGV_ACCERR, si_addr=}
SIGSEGV {si_signo=SIGSEGV, si_code=SI_KERNEL, si_addr=NULL}
```
I suppose to increase interactive console main loop fiber stack. This would fix problem reported as this bug. 
On attempt to create console fiber(with default stack size), fiber would fail; but would not crash tarantool.
tarantool> require('fiber').create(function() require('console').start() end)
We didn't have constructive discussion, and I have no constructive ideas that could resolve this problem systematically. Third-party libraries RPM compile flags are the part of distros and it could be reproduced in some other cases later.

First of all, "We don't support SQLite's binding mechanism" - it is not so. I've validated assigning variable and it works correctly. The problem is slightly different:
sql_trigger_begin use reduced expression tree for WHEN clause:
trigger->pWhen = sqlite3ExprDup(db, when, EXPRDUP_REDUCE);
so, iColumn that is below iTable field (#define EXPR_REDUCEDSIZE offsetof(Expr,iTable))
is an invalid memory containing zero:
u32 nSize = (u32) exprStructSize(p);
            memcpy(zAlloc, p, nSize);
            if (nSize < EXPR_FULLSIZE) {
                memset(&zAlloc[nSize], 0,
                       EXPR_FULLSIZE - nSize);
            }
as you see, EXPRDUP_REDUCE even doesn't save memory in this case!. And there is an other feature that cause this bug: sql{expr, view, trigger}_compile modify parser state, including allocated variables. This changes should affect main parser if any.
But we don't have parser on server side.. I think that DEFAULTS/VIEWS/CHECKS and other server-integrated(compiled with temporal parser) AST Variables would work improper way. 
I mean, assigned variables of all this parsers are uncorrelated, may overlap;
Variables are looking like a thing that we should get rid off.. Moreover, I offer this diff

trigger->pColumns = sqlite3IdListDup(db, columns);

(columns != NULL && trigger->pColumns == NULL))
goto trigger_cleanup;
trigger->pWhen = when;
when = NULL;
trigger->pColumns = columns;
columns = NULL;

The reason for this strange behavior is that luaL_serializer uses storage optimization to excessively sparse arrays - they are represented as a MP_MAP. Thus, in luamp_encode_tuple, the luamp_encode routine returns MP_MAP instead of MP_ARRAY. Due to the fact that the data in Tarantool tuples are represented as MP_ARRAY, this is unacceptable.
I.e.: for this schema
s2:frommap({bucket_id=12477, createDate="2018-12-13T12:46:10.000+0000", id="617f257e-2add-4168-b7fa-0c21189981a1", customerId=1, interactionItems={}})
Tuple is looking like this
['617f257e-2add-4168-b7fa-0c21189981a1', 1, 12477, '2018-12-13T12:46:10.000+0000', null, null, null, null, null, null, null, null, []]
We must set encode_sparse_ratio in luaL_serializer instance to disable this optimization.. ```

Could you pls check if it is working for you?. @pgulutzan, could you pls propose an order, which is correct from your point of view?. This still looks like a bug to me.
Looks Oracle [1] FK checks are performed after AFTER trigger invocation.
In PostgreSQL [2] AFTER triggers are fired after all constraints are checked.
As I understand the Standard (4.39.2 Trigger execution):
For each state change SCj in SEC, the BEFORE triggers activated by SCj are executed before any of their triggering
events take effect. When those triggering events have taken effect, any AFTER triggers activated by the
state changes of SEC are executed.
AFTER triggers are fired after triggered event is taken effect.  Triggered events are
INSERT, UPDATE etc. So, AFTER triggers are fired after change takes place and
hence all constraints are checked. So, I guess PostgreSQL for rigid w.r.t. ANSI here.
@pgulutzan what do you think? Proposal is to defer AFTER triggers after all
constraints are checked.

39. I think so. But, this is still temporal solution and all those errors should be integrated into Tarantool's backend in future.. It turns out, that it's time to split program logic for DDL and DML a bit.
Any DDL operation lead to schema change, so any reference to space* or
index* would become invalid.
Proposal is to distinguish DDL operations like this:
1. If operation is about to change schema ID (any update to _space, _index,
_truncate), then special handling is needed. Any operation of such a king
need to use space_id/index_id explicitly
2. New opcode to be introduced which will derive pointer to space/index
from its identifier
3. All DML operations should use references to space/index, not
identifiers
Schema might only be changed during DDL request.
Schema might not be changed during DML request.

  30 SeekRowid        3   32    1               00 intkey=r[1]; pk
  31 Rowid            3    9    0               00 r[9]=rowid
  32 IsNull           9   40    0               00 if r[9]==NULL goto 40
  33 String8          0   10    0 table         00 r[10]='table'
  34 String8          0   11    0 t2            00 r[11]='t2'
  35 String8          0   12    0 t2            00 r[12]='t2'
  36 Copy             2   13    0               00 r[13]=r[2]
  37 String8          0   14    0 CREATE TABLE t2(id INT) 00 r[14]='CREATE TABLE t2(id INT)'
  38 MakeRecord      10    5   15 BBBDB         00 r[15]=mkrec(r[10..14])
  39 Insert           3   15    9               00 intkey=r[9] data=r[15]
  40 SetCookie        0    1    4               00
  41 ParseSchema      0    0    0 tbl_name='t2' AND type!='trigger' 00
  42 Halt             0    0    0               00
  43 Transaction      0    1    3 0             01 usesStmtJournal=1
  44 Goto             0    1    0               00
So, inside single VM program both DDL (stmts 1-10) and 
DML (rest) requests are put together.
Proposal is to use identifiers in DDL, pointers in DML and
special opcode on the border, which will derive pointer from
identifier. Also separate opcode for insertion by identifier
is needed. It will be used for insertions into spaces which might
lead to schema ID change.
Here's proposed pseudocode (for same create table as select):
...
MakeRecord r1, ... ; Prepare tuple for _space insertion
InsertS <_space_id>, r1 ; Insert new tuple into _space space
...
MakeRecord r2, ... ; Prepare tuple for _index insertioon
InsertS <_index_id>, r2 ; Insert new tuple into _index space
...
SIDtoPtr <t1>, r3; t1 is a table which if donor for values to new table
SIDtoPtr <t2>, r4; t2 is newly created table. <t2> is on reg probably
...
OpenRead 1, r3 ; Open is performed by pointer
...
OpenWrite 2, r4; Open is performed by pointer
;; Loop over 1 and insert into 2
At the end of the day, new opcodes are to be introduced:
1. InsertS for insertions into tables which might change schema ID
2. OpenRead/OpenWrite should use pointer to space/index as argument
3. SIDtoPtr is new opcode which is a barrier between DDL and DML and
should convert space identifier to pointer.
4. No subsequent schema changes are allowed. This should be checked
(in debug mode) by assertions in OpenRead/OpenWrite

. The main part of this issue is exposing expressions-related parts of parser to Tarantool's core.
I.e. make it possible to store SQL expression (string value) in, say, field_def structure and during
preparation of tuple_fieldto be able to translate it into AST, struct Expr *.
This AST can be used during byte code generation if, say, a default value is to be inserted.
Need to introduce a flag which will tell to parser, that all is needed is AST, no bytecode should be
emitted. This flag should also signal that no name resolution should be performed: default
expression is parsed during DDL and struct space* is not exists so far. Name resolution
should be performed later on.
The context of expression is really not wide: only constants and built-in functions are allowed
for DEFAULT and only table under construction columns for CHECK constraint. Hence,
approach would be:
1. Introduce a flag signalling that no name resolution to be performed by parser and no byte-code
to be emitted
2. Convert expression string to "SELECT " and invoke the parser
3. Find parsed struct Expr* in result struct Select* or report error
This approach should work also for CHECK constraints and maybe partial indexes.

For memtx such trigger set here:
```
memtx_engine_begin(struct engine engine, struct txn txn)
{
        (void)engine;
        /
         * Register a trigger to rollback transaction on yield.
         * This must be done in begin(), since it's
         * the first thing txn invokes after txn->n_stmts++,
         * to match with trigger_clear() in rollbackStatement().
         /
        if (txn->is_autocommit == false) {
            trigger_create(&txn->fiber_on_yield, txn_on_yield_or_stop,
                            NULL, NULL);
            trigger_create(&txn->fiber_on_stop, txn_on_yield_or_stop,
                            NULL, NULL);

```
So, if no insertions were performed, no rollback will be fired on console's
fiber yield.
E.g.:
```
tarantool> commit;

...
tarantool> begin;
...
tarantool> select 1;



[1]
...



tarantool> commit
...
However:
tarantool> begin

...
tarantool> insert into t1 values (1)
...
tarantool> commit

error: cannot commit - no transaction is active
...
```

. I was able to successfully build and install Tarantool 1.5 after applying 2 patches.
`` ruby
    ohai "Preparing"
    version =git -C #{cached_download} describe HEAD`
File.open(buildpath/"VERSION", 'w') {|file| file.write(version)}
system "patch", "-p0", "third_party/libeio/ecb.h", "01_ecb.patch"
system "patch", "-p0", "third_party/libev/ev.c", "02_ev.patch"

```
01_ecb.patch
```
--- third_party/libeio/ecb.h    2016-05-23 16:41:55.000000000 +0300
+++ third_party/libeio/ecb.h.patched    2016-05-23 16:41:43.000000000 +0300
@@ -82,7 +82,7 @@
#define ECB_C     (STDC+0) / this assumes that STDC is either empty or a number /
 #define ECB_C99   (STDC_VERSION >= 199901L)
-#define ECB_C11   (STDC_VERSION >= 201112L)
+#define ECB_C11   0  // (STDC_VERSION >= 201112L)
 #define ECB_CPP   (__cplusplus+0)
 #define ECB_CPP11 (__cplusplus >= 201103L)
```
02_ev.patch
```
--- third_party/libev/ev.c  2015-04-22 19:43:04.000000000 +0300
+++ third_party/libev/ev.c.patched  2016-05-23 16:50:11.000000000 +0300
@@ -559,7 +559,7 @@
#define ECB_C     (STDC+0) / this assumes that STDC is either empty or a number /
 #define ECB_C99   (STDC_VERSION >= 199901L)
-#define ECB_C11   (STDC_VERSION >= 201112L)
+#define ECB_C11   0  // (STDC_VERSION >= 201112L)
 #define ECB_CPP   (__cplusplus+0)
 #define ECB_CPP11 (__cplusplus >= 201103L)
```
. To use it smoothly, I also had to change the following in tarantool.rb
``
--- tarantool.rb    2016-05-23 17:18:53.000000000 +0300
+++ tarantool.rb.patched    2016-05-23 17:18:41.000000000 +0300
@@ -50,6 +50,8 @@
     version =git -C #{cached_download} describe HEAD`
 File.open(buildpath/"VERSION", 'w') {|file| file.write(version)}


system "patch", "-p0", "third_party/libeio/ecb.h", "01_ecb.patch"

system "patch", "-p0", "third_party/libev/ev.c", "02_ev.patch"
ohai "Configuring:"
 system "cmake", ".", *args
@@ -59,6 +61,8 @@
ohai "Installing:"
 system "make install"
+    system "mkdir", "-p", "#{prefix}/var/run"
+    system "mkdir", "-p", "#{prefix}/var/lib/tarantool"
ohai "Installing man"
 man1.install 'doc/man/tarantool.1'
@@ -69,6 +73,7 @@
 ohai "Installing config"
 if build.stable?
   inreplace prefix/"etc/tarantool.cfg", /^work_dir =./, "work_dir = #{prefix}/var/lib/tarantool"
+      inreplace prefix/"etc/tarantool.cfg", /^pid_file =./, "pid_file = #{prefix}/var/run/box.pid"
 else
   doc.install "test/box/box.lua"
   inreplace doc/"box.lua" do |s|
```
.

. Yes, I use github.com/tarantool/go-tarantool which -- as far as I know -- is the official Go client library (?)
Yes, the test app is (partly) a benchmark, and yes, the rate at which it makes Tarantool requests is not limited by anything, it just goes as fast as it can.
I don't think there is any throttling in the Go client library...
... and IMHO it would be the wrong place to fix it (the client library can't possibly know if the server can accept more requests... unless you implement some sort of feedback loop, in every client driver for every language... complicating things...).
Can readahead be dynamic? So box.cfg would specify the maximum size, not initial?
Pinging @mialinx Go client maintainer.
. The client stops reading -- but server does keep sending responses?
If that's the case, then it sounds more like a client bug.
And just want to note that I have tried setting the client side timeout to some ridiculously large value, and it did not help (it still failed, just took longer).
. And another thing worth noting, in favor of a client library bug:
My test app uses synchronous Tarantool calls -- I mean it does not queue up a large number of requests only then waiting for them to complete.
And it's my understanding that every call to e.g. dbconn.CallTyped 1) sends a request to Tarantool and 2) waits for a response and 3) only then returns.
And so, there should be at most 20 (the number of worker threads) outstanding requests in and at most 20 outstanding responses.

/usr/local/Homebrew/Library/Homebrew/shims/super/clang   -fexceptions -funwind-tables -fno-common -fopenmp -msse2 -DCHECK_FUNCTION_EXISTS=clock_gettime -mavx -isysroot /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Platforms/MacOSX.platform/Developer/SDKs/MacOSX10.12.sdk -mmacosx-version-min=10.11 -Wl,-search_paths_first -Wl,-headerpad_max_install_names   CMakeFiles/cmTC_ad457.dir/CheckFunctionExists.c.o  -o cmTC_ad457
```
. The underlying cause is the new SDK's weak symbols:
iMac-TMP:SDKs joe$ pwd
/Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Platforms/MacOSX.platform/Developer/SDKs
iMac-TMP:SDKs joe$ grep 'weak$os10.11' MacOSX.sdk/usr/lib/system/libsystem_c.tbd
    symbols:         [ '$ld$weak$os10.11$_basename_r', '$ld$weak$os10.11$_clock_getres', 
                       '$ld$weak$os10.11$_clock_gettime', '$ld$weak$os10.11$_clock_settime', 
                       '$ld$weak$os10.11$_dirname_r', '$ld$weak$os10.11$_getentropy', 
                       '$ld$weak$os10.11$_mkostemp', '$ld$weak$os10.11$_mkostemps', 
iMac-TMP:SDKs joe$
iMac-TMP:SDKs joe$ grep clock_gettime MacOSX.sdk/usr/include/time.h 
int clock_gettime(clockid_t __clock_id, struct timespec *__tp);
__uint64_t clock_gettime_nsec_np(clockid_t __clock_id);
So it's defined but not actually available, and you won't find that out at build time unless you pass -no_weak_imports in LDFLAGS. But you can't easily do that because that flag is not supported on earlier versions of Xcode, including the CLT 7.3.1 which is the latest available for 10.11. So even if Xcode 8 is installed, using -no_weak_imports can still fail.
But assuming you don't pass -no_weak_imports it will find the symbol is defined in time.h and compile. But then crash at run time. So the most reliable check is that it both builds and executes, since simply successfully compiling does not mean you actually have the symbol available at runtime anymore.

hishamhm:
It's a matter of having your own tarantool manifest in luarocks.org, and confoguring your luarocks client so that the tarantool manifest takes precedence over the root one. not in the tarantool manifest, right?. Since it's not a fork, it would be really nice (and less confusing for your users) if you didn't rename it completely. A name like luarocks-tarantool or tarantool-luarocks (tab-completion for the win :) ) would make it clearer for users what is it that they're using. After all, they will have to go to the LuaRocks documentation to read about writing rockspecs, etc.
Users seeing tarantoolpm will think that this is a further fragmentation of the package manager ecosystem, just like recently happened with OpenResty's opm. :-(
Also, I'm not sure if there are significant advantages in stripping the main script down. You'll have greater documentation overhead and users will lose useful features (like luarocks doc and luarocks show). If you say "it's just vanilla luarocks configured to use the tarantool paths" you'll be able to point users to the LuaRocks documentation as-is. I would really just use a wrapper with a custom config. It will make maintenance and packaging easier for you. No worries to keep the code in sync: note that the modules used by the main luarocks script are not a public API.

Install tarantool-version.rockspec stub into /var/lib/tarantoolpm/ to allow "dependencies { tarantool = "1.7.4" }

This is not necessary. You can enter rocks_provided = { tarantool = "1.7.4" } in the config file and it will behave as such. :)
But overall, I think the idea of shipping an instance of LuaRocks configured for the tarantool specificities is in the right direction! 👍 . @rtsisyk Ah, that sounds like a very interesting approach! I like it! (And kudos for using the name rock as a pointer to LuaRocks. This could become a pattern for LuaRocks-embedded-in-applications in the future.)
Note that we don't really provide a stable API for LuaRocks internals other than the command-line, so bundling an internal copy of LuaRocks and launching it via os.execute is the safest bet, while we don't have a library API. We do want to have a library API eventually, but running luarocks command is not a performance-critical operation anyway, so the os.execute approach should be enough at least as a first approach. If you do decide to plug into LuaRocks internals directly, well, you're free to do so of course, but since we don't have a public API I thought it would be responsible of me to say so. :).

but it does not help. :(. Looks like easiest way to reproduce these issue is:

Configure host machine to get address from DHCP
Configure network interface with allow-hotplug option (default on Debian), so the corresponding /etc/network/interfaces would look like this:


allow-hotplug ens33
iface ens33 inet dhcp

In this case networking.service will not know when this hotplug will happens, and return control immediately. So, trantool starts before DHCP obtains address.
To overcome the issue it is enough to configure interface with auto option.
Although this is a way to reproduce the issue, it is clear miconfiguration - no one in reality will configure server to get address with DHCP and specify specific IP in listen address.
However the same issue holds true for DNS name in listen address - in will not be resolved during tarantool startup in described scenario.
May be it is worth to mention proper interface configuration in documentation with warning about allow-hotplug option?. Also, it would be wonderful if local clients were able to connect using unix-socket, while replication works over TCP..

Assertion failed: (pMem->enc < 5), function sqlite3VdbeMemPrettyPrint,
file /Users/b.niatshin/tarantool/src/box/sql/vdbe.c, line 465.. There are two possible solutions:
No. 1:
Do not do SQLite-style REPLACE logic for unique keys.
Do it only for primary keys, as in Tarantool/NoSQL.
Therefore ON CONFLICT REPLACE is only legal for one
key in the table (the primary key), and the problem
of multiple ON CONFLICT REPLACE actions disappears.
No. 2
Check the ON CONFLICT REPLACE constraint, and if
it says "violation" then DELETE with DELETE rules.
Do the insert's BEFORE triggers.
Do all constraint checks for unique, check, and foreign-key,
including the ones that have ON CONFLICT REPLACE clauses, but this
time the result of conflict is always an error.
Do the statement action itself (update|insert|delete).
Do all AFTER triggers.
The problem with 2nd approach is that the order of execution also involves execution of Tarantool triggers, which happens after checking all constraints.
So we need to decide which approach we should take into account.. Blocked by #3293 . Now in SQL NOT NULL constraint is checked by bytecode. If we remove it and rely on Tarantool, it won't work. Example:
```
tarantool> create table t1(a int primary key, b NOT NULL);
tarantool> insert into t1 values (1, 1);
tarantool> insert into t1 values (2, NULL);

...
tarantool> SELECT * FROM t1;

[2, null]
```. Key problem is that we have syntax error and fallback error.

Fallback is when you use keyword in not appropriate place, for example you can execute next statement:
CREATE TABLE ABORT(a int primary key);
We have "ABORT" keyword with token type TK_ABORT, we have fallback rule in parse.y which says to fallback TK_ABORT to TK_ID (identifier token type), therefore error doesn't happen. If you try something else without fallback rule, you will get an error.
Key of the problem is that parser doesn't separate fallback errors and syntax errors, handling of that situation now is being done in the same parser state. If both happens and last processed keyword is reserved, we will see message 'keyword "KEYWORD" is reserved" like in the example above, not 'syntax error ... '. 
We need to implement %fallback_error clause for lemon and to distinct fallback error and syntax error and to make syntax error priority higher.
. After discussion with @kyukhin we came to decision that 'not optimal execution analyze plan' is temporarily okay for us.. Patch is in 2.0, so that ticket should be closed.. First thing to do in order to accomplish that ticket is OP_OpenWrite removal, because Tarantool doesn't require opened cursor for executing write operation. The only necessary information is
space_id (for usual spaces) or struct space (for ephemeral spaces), pointer to tuple and tuple length.
However, OP_OpenRead and OP_OpenWrite implementations are absolutely the same right now, for both READ and WRITE operations VDBE creates new cursor.
The main problem is that we have to overcome is dependence of OP_IdxInsert from OP_OpenWrite.
That problem consists of several components:
1) OpenWrite extracts necessary information about space and fills it into pKeyInfo field inside cursor, assigns BTCF_TaCursor flag. But the only thing we need to know about index is the amount of fields inside.
2) pKeyInfo will be used later during execution of IdxInsert. First of all, it is necessary to determine in which type of space we are inserting - usual or ephemeral (different API calls will be done). It is done by checking cursor flag.
     Usual spaces have space_id attribute, so for them it is not necessary to have related cursor
     in order to accomplish box_insert/box_replace operation, only space_id, tuple and tuple length.
     However, ephemeral spaces doesn't have space_id attribute, you need to know pointer to
     ephemeral space. And that pointer is stored inside ta_cursor structure, which is a part of VDBE
    cursor.
3) During query compilation we doesn't know in which type of space we are inserting - usual or ephemeral. Right know we are able to determine it only in real-time by checking cursor flags.
We need to get rid of cursors in IdxInsert for usual spaces and to open cursors only for ephemeral ones.
Possible solution is to pass into p4 register (which a union, not an int register) a pointer to structure, which will contain space_id and struct space *. We may somehow know that information during compile time (I don't know how, need to ask @Korablev77 about that). That will allow us to separate ephemeral spaces from a usual ones. If space is usual, then that struct will have assigned space_id, if ephemeral - then pointer to struct space.
Anyway, this is a non-trivial ticket which totally deserves team discussion.

Currently we are working on static types. I've checked your list and that is what we have now:

It is mandatory to state a data type.
Therefore this becomes illegal:
CREATE TABLE t (s1 PRIMARY KEY);
It is mandatory to state a data type by its
name or by its synonym. The current method

The stated data type is a statement of a
