It is done (but still not hit the trunk - it is on the branch). Now every column must feature type.

CHAR (synonyms CHARACTER),
VARCHAR (synonyms CHAR VARYING, CHARACTER VARYING),
SMALLINT,
INT (synonyms INTEGER),
FLOAT,
REAL,
DOUBLE PRECISION (non-standard synonym DOUBLE),
NUMERIC,
DECIMAL (synonym DEC),
DATE,
TIME,
TIMESTAMP.

Almost all of these types are supported by syntax, but they are mapped onto poor set of available types in Tarantool (in fact, only integer, number, string and scalar for blob).
Issues below are aimed at extending this set:
Introduce SMALLINT and BIGINT types: https://github.com/tarantool/tarantool/issues/3687
Introduce scale and precision for numeric types: https://github.com/tarantool/tarantool/issues/3672
Introduce string type with fixed length: https://github.com/tarantool/tarantool/issues/3665
Introduce BOOLEAN type: https://github.com/tarantool/tarantool/issues/3648
Introduce DATETIME type: https://github.com/tarantool/tarantool/issues/3694

It is illegal to assign or compare
values of incompatible data types.
There are no automatic incompatible-to-compatible
conversions.
Ranges of values and lengths are limited by their
definitions and those limits are to be enforced.
Therefore these become illegal:
UPDATE t SET integer_column = 'x';
UPDATE t SET character_column_with_length_4 = 'ABCDE';
UPDATE t SET smallint_column = 999999;

 101>    7 FCopy            7    2    3               00 reg[2@cur_frame]= reg[7@root_frame(O0LAG_SAME_FRAME)]. The order of action in case of DROP TABLE statement in original SQLite:
1. Begin transaction
2. Remove statistics from sql_stat1 and sql_stat4, if any exists
3. Delete all rows from table and for each row which violates FK constraint emit OP_FkCounter += 1
4. Check for foreign key constraint (OP_FkCounter and OP_FkIfZero)
5. End transaction
If any stage fails(for instance due to presence of child table), then transaction will rollback. 
In Tarantool there is no support for multi-statement transactions, so it is not possible to rollback. In this case, even if DROP TABLE failed, the table would remain empty after 3 stage.
Possible solution:
Firstly, check for all constraints and only then truncate table. But this seems to be too obvious, 
so there could be pitfalls.
upd: Solution above fails due to several reasons. Firstly, to check foreign key violation VDBE uses special register-counter: when deleted/inserted row leads to violation, this counter is incremented. So if we want to immediately prevent from deleting rows which violate FK constraint from table, we should add OP_FkIfZero before each row removal. This could lead to significant increase of VDBE opcodes in each prepared statement. Moreover, all rows deleted before row which violates FK will be removed irretrievably. Another problem lies in ON CASCADE operation: we shouldn't raise an error, if all child table feature ON DELETE CASCADE option.. Well, I would provide more detailed explanation. When OP_MakeRecord allocates memory, it uses sqlite3VdbeMsgpackRecordLen() to estimate size of needed memory before place there encoded in msgpack record. However, this function relies on certain heuristics and return sort of upper bound of required memory. Later, when msgpack is put into this memory by sqlite3VdbeMsgpackRecordPut(), real size of msgpack is calculated. And it turns out to be less, than first estimation.
It is worth mentioning that the difference between these two values could be significant: up to 5-6 times for small records. Thus, a lot of memory is wasted, i.e. allocated but not used.
On the other hand, precise calculation of required memory would demand extra cpu cycles. Hence, even if this feature going to be implemented, it should be carefully benchmarked.. Is this proposal OK for you?. Actually, they don't have to be unique. Reason for such behaviour is quite simple: SQLite uses rowid for stat tables, meanwhile Tarantool doesn't. Instead, PK consists of two (or three for stat4) columns: table, index and sample (for stat4). However, they might coincide: analyze updates information in stat tables in runtime.
As for your example, approximate execution plan of analyze consists of several stages:
1. For t1b index only one sample exists -- 2.
2. After first row has been procceeded, stat table looks like: ("t1", "t1b", 0, 0, 0, "2").
3. After second row has been handled, new statistic to be inserted is: ("t1", "t1b", 1, 1, 0, "2").
(It may be a little bit different, but the meaning is the same).
As you can see, without replacing we can't update tuple in stat table. That is why replace is used.
As concerning the fact that analyze routine doesn't work in optimal way -- yes, it seems to be not optimal. But we should carefully consider and discuss how to improve it before making some changes. Anyway, by design analyze should be run quite rarely, so I don't think that 'not optimal' execution plan can be a really significant issue.. The idea to allocate memory on region while making record firstly seemed to be reasonable (moreover, it has passed through review and got to trunk). However, ephemeral spaces have nothing in common with txn routine. Thus, txn_commit() won't release memory which is allocated on region to hold tuples to be inserted into ephemeral spaces. So, for ephemeral spaces we MUST (and it is not kind of optimisation as we thought before) allocate memory for records using ordinary malloc.
I can suggest following solutions:


Attempt at pointing out to which table (ephemeral or not) we are making record at the compilation time by setting flag in fifth register of OP_MakeRecord. It may be not so easy, since at compilation stage we are operating only with cursor numbers, so I am not sure that we always can differ them.


Passing cursor number (from which we are able to fetch space id) in the fifth register to OP_MakeRecord (almost like p.1, but we don't have to guess whether cursor with given number is ephemeral or not). On the other hand, it leads to additional moves at runtime (while executing this opcode). Meanwhile, it seems to be very hot and should be optimized as much as possible.


Brutally release all region memory after vdbe's halt. (Actually, it sounds like a nonsense)


Simply revert this patch. Without it allocation will always be using malloc, but before insertion to ordinary space tuple will be copied to region.


Contrary to p.4, always allocate on region, but before insertion to ephemeral space, tuple will be copied to malloc.. Well, p.3 really works (at least now, even if it is unlikely to be the most elegant solution).

A week ago we talked about unique constraints, indexes and compatibility of their names - in other words, should we be able to create unique constraint and unique index with the same name and should constraints and indexes share one namespace(?). I've checked three vendors (PostgreSQL, Oracle and MySQL) and all of them feature one namespace for unique constraints and indexes. On the other hand, it is clear that indexes are separated from SQL ANSI and the fact that unique constraint implements index under the hood is the question of DB design. Nevertheless, I'm not sure that we want separate these namespaces. I would better poll other members. Still, we can do it: all we need is to mangle unique constraint name, create index with mangled name and the original one save to constraint namespace.. >  If a user explicitly specifies index name via CONSTRAINT , then he will expect to have this name both available via box.space.index.
Why? As I already mentioned, index is only an implementation of unique constraint, so generally speaking creation of unique constraint may not lead to creation of index (I guess that all DBs follow this way, but it is not stated in standard). For example, in PostgreSQL:
select typname from pg_type where oid = pg_typeof(9007199254740992.0)
   | typname
-- | --
1  | numeric
We can force DOUBLE type and observe the same loss:

float8
9,00719925474099E+15
Since literals are threatened as doubles, they obey IEEE 754 standard. And by this standard loss is expected behaviour. Hence until numeric/decimal types are introduced, we can do nothing here.
I suggest to document the fact that literals are threatened as floating point numbers (not as numeric ones - moreover, it should be obvious since we don't have numeric type at all) and close this issue.. Literal is parsed without loss, it is simply saved as a string. String is converted to double during byte-code generation (see codeReal() function). It is out of parser's business, you get the same 'loss' in C:
double x = 9223372036854775807.0;
printf("%f \n", x);
9223372036854775808.000000
So, when numeric appears on-board, we will define default parameters for numeric literals and convert string exactly to this precision. If it can't be converted without loss, we will throw an error.
Integer features quite different nature, and this error seems to be OK. Again, if we had numeric type and literals were threatened as numeric, then no error would be raised. The same example from PosgtreSQL:
```
select typname from pg_type where oid = pg_typeof(9223372036854775808)
   | typname
-- | --
1  | numeric

22003: integer out of range
```
So, I guess this error is fine.

upd.: wow, this behaviour was made on purpose (see sqlite3ColumnsFromExprList):
if (cnt > 3)
                sqlite3_randomness(sizeof(cnt), &cnt);. > Looks like this might be a reason for SQL UPDATES being so slow.
Do you have any benchmarks proving that? If so, lets attach them to this ticket, so that we make sure that after reworking UPDATE we will gain real performance improvements.. It turns out that problem seems to be more fundamental: to compile some specific queries (see example below) we fall into recursion consisting of two functions: sqlite3ExprCodeTemp and sqlite3ExprCodeTarget. These functions consume approximately 528 bytes (416 + 112) of stack memory per call. Since we are limited with 64kb of fiber stack, it results in ~110 depth recursion. To prove this point we can execute that simple query:
box.cfg{}
sql = "SELECT 1 "
for i = 1, 106 do
    sql = sql .. string.format("+ %s ", i)
end
box.sql.execute(sql)
Bus error: 10
More sophisticated queries may require even less recursion depth to cause stack overflow.
Now as a workaround we can restrict AST hight with 100, but surely - it is temporary solution.
As a radical solution - we should reimplement all recursion calls implementing AST traversal without recursion (for example - using stack). In addition, we also can increase fiber stack size for SQL parser processing.
Also, note that ASAN significantly increases stack memory consumption, resulting in 4353 bytes per two calls (256 and 4096 respectively). Hence even 10 members within expr can lead to stack overflow:
```
sql = "SELECT 1 "
for i = 1, 9 do
    sql = sql .. string.format("+ %s ", i)
end
box.sql.execute(sql)

now is blocked by #4023 . Ok, my bad. Indeed, in the first example it's not an aggregate. But still, result looks confusing: to determine largest of the supplied expressions, they must be comparable. String literal 'str' and integer literal 1 are unlikely to be comparable in any sense (ofc we can implicitly cast int to str and compare two strings '1' and 'str', but I suppose this way is not what we really want).. There is a huge mess with blob and scalar types. Fortunately, we've realised that and decided to remove blob as a valid type and allow instead scalar type (since we failed to provide decent support of BLOB using only SCALAR; we need independent type integrated into NoSQL as well). And it is in scope of 2.1.2 release. SCALAR is a type-aggregation for all other types (available in SQL: INTEGER, NUMBER and STRING), i.e. its behaviour is the same as in NoSQL. Anyway, some day we will have to introduce that type in SQL to make it consistent with NoSQL. BLOB as a term still exists in SQL internals and in fact it represents strings to be encoded as MP_BIN (which matches definition of BLOB in NoSQL internals). For details, see doc request on this subject: https://github.com/tarantool/doc/issues/735
Ok, back to your example. Since BLOB doesn't mean SCALAR now (in every sense), it should result in error. If you have any questions concerning SQL SCALAR type (mb you will notice some bugs or general misbehaviour) or this particular issue, we can discuss it in dev mailing list.. What are the possibilities of supporting a RETURNING clause from INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE and returning all the modified tuples?
This a most useful feature and could be a nice addition.  Also when used along with CTEs you have a good way to return the outcome of INSERTS, UPDATES or DELETES and pass them into INSERTS, UPDATES or DELETES.  Utilizing this type of SQL query can simplify many scenarios.
Another neat thing may be even a way to directly enqueue deleted or updated tuples into a queue if they where addressable through SQL.

ImeevMA:
At the end it was decided to return all auto-generated in current statement ids. It will be used in JDBC driver: getGeneratedKeys(). After some research I found out:
ODBC
According to documentation:
Each INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE statement returns a result set containing only the number of rows affected by the modification.
JDBC
According to documentation:
Each INSERT statement returns a result set. This result set can contain:
1. Number of rows affected by the modification.
2. All auto-generated in this statement keys. Method getGeneratedKeys() is used to get these auto-generated values. This method returns ResultSet object. However, what data contains this object should be decided by vendor.
After this I read what other vendor returns. I found that in case flag RETURN_GENERATED_KEYS was used returned ResultSet contains:
DB2: All values that were generated during this INSERT statement. Does not work with executeBatch().
PostgreSQL: All columns of all inserted records. Works with executeBatch().
MS SQL: Only one generated value. This is bug. Does not work with executeBatch().
Oracle DB: ROWID of inserted row. This ROWID can be used to retrieve other columns. Does not work with executeBatch().
Now we have to decide what to return via IPROTO:
1) Only auto-generated IDs.
2) All rows in which ID was generated.
3) All rows.
4) Nothing (in this case getGeneratedKeys() should throw SQLFeatureNotSupportedException).. Hello, @pgulutzan!

So, I am not sure about special log format for journald, because we do have level (I, V, D, etc), moreover journalctl can distinguish them. I guess the ticket was opened because of log level filtration, and it mostly works.
In case of stream output - there is no filtration. I sent stdout and stderr to journal.

systemd-cat tarntool

The output is indistinguishable for journal filtration.
If we really need this in server we can change plain format:
 * YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss.ms [PID]: CORD/FID/FIBERNAME LEVEL> MSG
to YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss.ms [PID]: CORD/FID/FIBERNAME LEVEL> MSG
But if we do so, we should get rid of json format, because it will be useless(because journalctl has option json-pretty).
So, we need to decide what to do: do nothing and recommend to use syslog logging for journal, change plain format slightly or add additional format journal..

This is a real issue. 
You can only drop an object which has no grants on it. That's why tarantool first
revokes all the privileges on object before dropping it. Granting and revoking
privileges on an object is allowed only for admin and object owner, that's why
it demands REVOKE privilege, which can't be granted, as mentioned above.
But even if you try to drop an object which has no privileges on it, you will
fail, because your DROP privilege on the object will already be revoked.
So the only way to drop an object is to have DROP access on entire entity,
which allows you to drop any object of that type. This is obviously wrong.

Hollow111:
Comparing invalid characters principles in other DMBSs:
DB2:
- Allows keeping invalid utf-8 characters inside of varchar, but '%'
and '_' in pattern skip any symbols in string regardless of validity.
("SELECT * FROM table1 WHERE smth LIKE '%'" returns all the rows from the table)
reproduce:
[[
    CREATE TABLE t(smth VARCHAR(10) PRIMARY KEY) CCSID Unicode
    INSERT INTO t VALUES ('ab' || X'D0')
    SELECT * FROM t WHERE smth
    SELECT * FROM t WHERE smth LIKE ('a%')
    SELECT * FROM t WHERE smth LIKE ('ab%')
]]
MySQL:
-  Doesn't let inserting invalid utf-8 characters.
-  But it still allows comparing invalid strings (it doesn't match them though whilst '%' still skips invalid characters).
reproduce:
1
[[
    create table t(a char(100));
    insert into t values (convert(0xD0, char(100)));
]]
2
[[
    select convert(0xD0, char(100)) like convert(0xD0, char(100));
    select convert(0xD0, char(100)) like '%';
]]
PostreSQL:
- PostgreSQL doesn't allow using non-utf symbols in string.
reproduce:
[[
    SELECT E'\xd0'
]]. In the current version of patch I have approximately tested
benefits of the xferOptimization using the following simple script:
```
fiber = require('fiber')
box = require('box')
box.cfg{}
avg_time_no_opt = 0
avg_time_opt = 0
max_iterator_value = 500000
for j = 1, 10 do
 box.sql.execute("create table t1(a primary key, b unique, c, d, f);")
 box.sql.execute("create table t2(a primary key, b, c unique, d, f);")
 box.sql.execute("create table t3(a primary key, b unique, c, d, f);")
 loop_timer1 = fiber.time()
 for i = 1, max_iterator_value do
  k4 = math.random(1, 50000)
  k5 = math.random(1, 50000)
  t = 'insert into t1 values (' .. i .. ',' .. i .. ',' .. i ..
      ',' .. k4 .. ',' .. k5 .. ');'
  box.sql.execute(t)
 end
 first_timer = fiber.time()
 box.sql.execute("insert into t2 select * from t1;")
 second_timer = fiber.time()
 avg_time_no_opt = avg_time_no_opt + second_timer - first_timer
 first_timer = fiber.time()
 box.sql.execute("insert into t3 select * from t1;")
 second_timer = fiber.time()
 avg_time_opt = avg_time_opt + second_timer - first_timer
 box.sql.execute('drop table t1;')
 box.sql.execute('drop table t2;')
 box.sql.execute('drop table t3;')
 loop_timer2 = fiber.time()
 print(loop_timer2 - loop_timer1)
end
avg_time_no_opt = avg_time_no_opt / 10
avg_time_opt = avg_time_opt / 10
print('Average insertion of ' .. max_iterator_value ..
      ' random 5-column tuples without optimization takes about ' ..
      avg_time_no_opt .. ' seconds.')
print('While the average insertion of the same data with xferOptimization ' ..
      'working takes about ' .. avg_time_opt .. ' seconds.')
```
Inserting 500 000 of 5-column tuples with no use of xferOptimization
takes approximately 4.25s to be processed.
Inserting the same data from the table to another one with identical schema
(hence the xferOptimization is used) takes approximately 3.74s to be processed,
which benefits about 13% of time.

cyrillos:
Guys, the real issue is not the page touching. But rather the fact that ncurses started to use 32K buffers since commit 1501ae2a13db0ffd2db8404c24aa5010a88ea91b (Mon Jan 22 01:39:40 2018 +0000)
@@ -94,7 +100,14 @@ extern "C" {
  * given implementation may exceed.
  */
 #define MAX_NAME_SIZE  512     /* maximum legal name field size (XSI:127) */
-#define MAX_ENTRY_SIZE 4096    /* maximum legal entry size */
+#define MAX_ENTRY_SIZE1        4096    /* maximum legal entry size (SVr2) */
+#define MAX_ENTRY_SIZE2        32768   /* maximum legal entry size (ncurses6.1) */
+
+#if NCURSES_EXT_COLORS && HAVE_INIT_EXTENDED_COLOR
+#define MAX_ENTRY_SIZE MAX_ENTRY_SIZE2
+#else
+#define MAX_ENTRY_SIZE MAX_ENTRY_SIZE1
+#endif
...
Now the callers
_nc_read_tic_entry
  char buffer[MAX_ENTRY_SIZE + 1];
  ...
  _nc_read_termtype
    char buf[MAX_ENTRY_SIZE + 2];
no wonder that it exceeds 65K stack. Page touching simply reveals the lack of stack early..
sorc1:
Please see pull request #3314.. To reproduce, just send SIGHUP to tarantool -e "box.cfg{log='test.log'}".
Note that tarantool -e "box.cfg{}" doesn't crash by SIGHUP but it just stops instead which shouldn't happen.
The problem is in signal_init() function. The function mistakenly sets two actions for SIGHUP via ev_signal_init(), in that order:
- signal_cb(), which terminates the server
- say_logrotate(), which rotates the logs
The first action just have to be removed. Before 9f99bc6 there was signal_cb() action but it was overwritten by signal() function. The signal() call was removed by the commit..

evanbates:
Hi, it was written that way to eliminate a step, i.e. the step of putting the file in "instances.available" and then creating a symlink to "instances.enabled" (similar to NGINX). In the interim, Tarantool has become more strict on the issue. So the thing to do is 
1. create the file in "instances.available," (step 1 should be "nano /etc/tarantool/instances.available/iplogger.lua")
2. Make a symlink: "ln -s /etc/tarantool/instances.available/iplogger.lua /etc/tarantool/instances.enabled"
3. After that the "tarantoolctl check" statements should pass.
p.s.  you also need to make sure to have the "http" module installed. This was part of 101 Part 1, but the easiest way to install it is with the cmake directions here: https://github.com/tarantool/http, like so: 
   git clone https://github.com/tarantool/http.git
   cd http && cmake . -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=RelWithDebugInfo 
   make
   make install
Let me know if you have any additional questions!. Changes also made in tutorial itself....

Fair enough.
I think lua-protobuf actually approximates lua_tonumberx() when it isn't available (i.e., LUA_VERSION_NUM < 502). And this is the same for any other library, unless they implement their own lua_tonumberx(), so it still might be worth adding to the exports lists..

```. Seems that the trouble is in concurrent request execution.
With this script (10 requests):
n = 10; http = require('http.client').new({max_connections=15}); clock = require('clock'); fiber = require('fiber'); elt = 0; for i=1,n do fiber.new(function () start=clock.monotonic64(); http:get('http://test:80/ucp/0001/account_types/account_type/13', {headers = {['bauth-token'] = '***'}, verbose = true}); eltc = tonumber(clock.monotonic64()-start) / 1000000000; require('log').info('== time elapsed: %f ==', eltc); elt = elt + eltc; end) end
First 4 requests are fast (~5 msec), other 6 are >100msec with increasing request time, the last one is 600msec
If keepalive* options are added, the situation is the same:
n = 10; http = require('http.client').new({max_connections=15}); clock = require('clock'); fiber = require('fiber'); elt = 0; for i=1,n do fiber.new(function () start=clock.monotonic64(); http:get('http://test:80/ucp/0001/account_types/account_type/13', {headers = {['Connection'] = 'keep-alive', ['bauth-token'] = '***'}, verbose = true, keepalive_idle = 75, keepalive_interval = 7200}); eltc = tonumber(clock.monotonic64()-start) / 1000000000; require('log').info('== time elapsed: %f ==', eltc); elt = elt + eltc; end) end
The last request execution time is 100 times bigger then the first 4.
With 50 requests: first 18 are 8 msec (almost equal execution time), last 22 are > 100msec, the last ones are 400msec.
With 100 requests: ~40 requests are fast, the last ones are 100 times slower.. > Try to increase the max_connections option (default is 5): 
It doesn't help (see, the number of connections in the test script is 15)..

Also found that the test hangs and on timeout leaves the opened socket with process holding ~780Mb of memory. To reproduce the issue occuring in 1-1.5% of single test loop runs, do:
for r in {1..1000} ; do ./test-run.py --no-output-timeout 3 box/push.test >/dev/null 2>&1 && continue ; echo "Fail reproduced ! check files:" ; ls -al var/001_box ; ps auxT | grep cat var/001_box/box.pid ; lsof -p cat var/001_box/box.pid ; break ; done
The detected issue test code appeared during fix of
https://github.com/tarantool/tarantool/issues/3859
at
https://github.com/tarantool/tarantool/commit/43af2de2b129dabafe94a61c89688dd4701f8800
. Suggested patch:
diff --git a/test/vinyl/errinj_ddl.test.lua b/test/vinyl/errinj_ddl.test.lua
index 95e0ad3c1..971b0ba1d 100644
--- a/test/vinyl/errinj_ddl.test.lua

@@ -155,7 +155,7 @@ errinj.set("ERRINJ_VY_RUN_WRITE_DELAY", false)
 ch:get()
s.index.sk:select()
-s.index.sk:stat().memory.rows
+test_run:wait_cond(function() return s.index.sk:stat().memory.rows == 27 end, 500)

@@ -165,12 +165,12 @@ errinj = box.error.injection
 s = box.space.test

-s.index.sk:stat().memory.rows
